column10:
A very unique game where you craft potions by using ingredients to move along a map.  Each ingredient has it's own path, which you only move partially on if you use the ingredient untreated.  If you crush the ingredients you can move further along the path.  You can also move back to the center by adding water.  There are obstacles that will ruin your potion, or just make things more inconvenient.  It sounds weird, and it kind of is but it's pretty fun and relaxing.  You run an alchemists shop and sell these potions to customers that ask for specific potions / effects.  The effects are stronger the closer you align the position on the map vs. the actual location.  You get new ingredients from a small garden and from travelling merchants.  There's not much more to the game.  Satisfy customers, use the gold to buy more ingredients and make more potions.  The potions eventually become more complex, needing multiple effects.  There are some weird rare ingredients and there are a few upgrades including a whole second map with some new obstacles.  And there are the special things you can craft that require multiple potions be placed into the alchemy machine in the basement.  I believe these eventually lead to the end game.

The major pros are the uniqueness and the relaxing nature of the game.  At least at first.  Also the tactile nature of the GUI is really nice, with you needing to stir the pot, move the pestle back and forth in the mortar, etc.

The cons would be the repetitive nature of the game, and how annoying advancing is later in the game.  You will need to do things like have a potion with 5 effects, get to potions in a maze of bones (things that destroy your potion), and make special ingredients that need lots of very specific and hard to make potions.  At first these challenging things are kind of fun, but it gets old and starts to become tedious and even frustrating.  Losing a potion because you think you can squeeze through an area and having to start over just becomes annoying later on.

So for me, the game is not recommended.  I pushed through most of the 6th alchemy path (out of 10 I think), and just realized I wasn't having fun anymore.  It looks like it was intended to have more things in the game like upgrading the spoon and stuff, but I'm pretty sure that isn't there.  It would have helped the game a lot.  I see this has "very positive" reviews, but less then 2% have actually finished it so I think this is mainly based off the early game.

[h2]Rating:  5.5/10[/h2]

[b]Explanation:[/b] Potion Craft , to me, is a game where the novelty wears off quickly. I put approx. 22 hours of time into the game but eventually dropped it because of how tedious it became. I wish I could like the game more as the art style and concept is wonderful, but the game feels forgotten about now. 

[i]Here is how my progression went:[/i]

The Beginning (1-5 hours): You spend time familiarizing yourself with the ingredients, and recipes, & the customer requests. Everything is new and sparkly and you have so much fun! Learning the in's and out of potion making is a great process. This is the space where you have so much hope and feel like you'll be obsessed with this for weeks. Although, at the end of hour 2 you've muted the music and put something else on. Listening to one track on repeat is too much. 

The Middle (6-15): Things are starting to slow down, you unlock harder and harder recipes, it's getting monotonous but with recipes you learn how to make things more efficient and less time consuming. 'Haggling' with merchants is a chore, but there are still some interesting and new ingredients out there. You hope you can unlock the tool upgrades soon. 

Middle Pt.2? (16+ hrs): You get tired of everything at this point. You are no longer reading the requests, just keywords, you angrily given them what they want and move on. You are praying for merchants to show up so you can finally get more  ingredients that you can't grow yourself (90% of them). Rapidly you are developing carpal tunnel in your hand and you realize there are no upgrades for your equipment at all. It was never put in the game. The objective of the game became too tedious and complex to manage and eventually you give up. 


If you are still really interested in this game I would suggest waiting for a sale. In it's current state it feels closer to 5-10USD, not 20.

I really love the game, but I do have some criticism. The general gameplay loop is awesome: Balancing ingredients and money, exploring the map, creating efficient recipes and upgrading the alchemy machine, all while tending the incoming requests. It's fun up to finishing the final ingredient...

The popularity level should be at about level 12 at that time, which means the last task is to grind ~3000 points to reach level 15. Wiith 39 points every day. The tasks are either "drag the standard potion from your book onto the scale" or "brew this really difficult potion with only 2 ingredients". It's not difficult to do the latter task, just annoying. The more efficient approach is to actually decline and just make up for it with more tasks in the same time. This shouldn't be the last thing to do to 100% the game. It should be mixing incredibly difficult potions to create [spoiler]the philosopher's stone[/spoiler].

Despite this I 100% recommend the game!

I just wish the finale would be the challenging puzzle, the game promises to be. Maybe there should be a mechanic like "quality" that requires a maximum number of ingredients used. That would turn the game into an incredible puzzle paradise!

It was enjoyable at the start, when you are figuring the game mechanics out.... and then it got boring really quick. Doesn't help that instructions are also not very clear, and the objective-fulfilling mechanics are rather wonky. I can be way early game and accidentally unlock multiple Chapter 5 objectives. 

When resources are limited and payoff of rejecting customers so drastic, it becomes very annoying and even possibly anxiety-inducing when trying to maximise the limited resources given. For the amount of ingredients given there are too many objectives at once (trying to satisfy customers, trying to stock up, trying to fulfil objectives, trying to get specific-level potions for the alchemy machine, etc), which demands further stretching of these resources. 

I really liked the idea of the whole thing, and I really tried to maximise my gameplay. I want to be supportive of the devs who put in their time and effort into making this - this game can be quite meditative, but with progression heavily dependent on grinding and overly calculative resource allocation, I can't really find it in myself to say my money was well spent. It will take this game to be less grindy and contain more progression before I can recommend it proper.

[h2] A Relaxing Yet Complex Alchemist Simulator [/h2]
As of writing this, players can nominate games for the 2023 Steam Awards. I recently chose my picks for each of the 11 categories and wanted to check out one of these games. That pick was for the Sit Back and Relax Award, for which I nominated the game [i] Potion Craft: Alchemist Simulator [/i]. After the slightly difficult experience of [i] Space Ace [/i], I thought I’d take a bit more of a relaxing turn with the next game I review.

In the game, you take on the role of a novice alchemist wandering the world and looking for a place to set up shop. In the town you come to, you come across an old abandoned home that you’ll turn into your alchemy base of operations and Potion Shop. The game begins with a tutorial that helps you learn the basics, which I found very helpful. I had never played this before, so that was much needed. But, from there, the game is pretty straightforward. As you make potions, you move around the Alchemy Map, picking up books for points that go toward skill points. Be careful of the sections of bones, as those will reset your progress, and the potion will fail.

While the game may be pretty straightforward in some places and complex in others, I had a lot of fun. Thankfully, this is one of those games where you can go at your own pace, which I took full advantage of. Also, there was enough of a challenge to this that I could stay engaged. Furthermore, I liked the art style and the music; I found it all quite charming if that's the right word. The mechanics were easy to get used to, too. However, it becomes repetitive, especially around the second half of the game, where you mainly make potions, sell them, buy valuable items for the Alchemy Machine, etc. Plus, getting those final achievements took a lot of work.

In conclusion, [i] Potion Craft [/i] is a fun, somewhat addicting, and unique kind of simulator with challenges but also a calming experience. If you’ve ever wanted to become an alchemist, now you can!

I started out loving this game; it's quite decent at what it sets out to do, which is as its name suggests, a potion crafting simulator. The thrill of discovering new ingredients and optimizing potions, however, quickly wears out. After a few days of play it simply becomes a slog of repetitive mechanics while venturing through a map where the excitement of discovery has plateaued. The addition of oil as a new base is a nice refresher, albeit a very temporary one. 

If that was the only criticism I had, however, I would still recommend the game as it was still quite enjoyable for however long you can bear the repetition, as with any sandbox/simulation style game. The main gripe is how the developers dangle these new mechanics which seemingly promise drastic changes to the game. After they hiked up the price, I was excited as I thought that it meant the update was coming soon. It has been probably over a year now and the only features they added were small fixes and features, while the elusive major update still loomed with no set date. 

As of now, the only things I do in the game is recreate old potions for the same customers, who very occasionally ask for a niche potion that I have to make from scratch. The alchemy set doesn't really add much to the game as it is essentially a disguised grinding mechanic. With all the potential it has, the late-game has essentially boiled down to a glorified Cookie Clicker. The one background track playing over and over also does not do it any favors. 

I do hope that the game developers focus more on replayability instead of novelty, as the game really has potential to be a casual game to play just for a few minutes. However, knowing that there really isn't a financial incentive to do so, it is just a pipe dream at this point.

I love games that have you run a shop, and there are already quite a few that involve alchemy. Unfortunately I find most of them struggle to make the potion-brewing element of the game interesting, often just asking you to discover recipes by mashing different herbs together. Well, Potion Craft is popular because the brewing mini-game is fantastic. They've managed to design a system that is relatively simple but gives the player the ability lots of room to be creative and strategic. 

There are many different ways to make the same potion, so you have to evaluate your priorities to decide which herbs to use. Is it more cost effective to use many cheap herbs or a couple of rare herbs? The customer would pay extra if I used certain herbs, but is it practical? I don't have many herbs usually needed to make a particular potion, should I just turn this customer away rather than make a really inefficient potion?

It's great. I've also rarely seen a shop game that does haggling very well, and I'd say Potion Craft scores mediocre on that. You make more money on each potion by playing a quick minigame where you have to click at the right time. You can choose the speed of the game - higher speed means higher reward but if you make a mistake the customer might end up with a discount. It's adequate, but simplistic and doesn't really feel like you're talking to someone. 

Also the game has a lovely hand-drawn aesthetic, with lots of little touches like the tip of your pestle changing colour based on the herb you just crushed with it. There are also quite a lot of customisation options for your potions like colour, label, shape of bottle etc. 

Overall I really enjoyed the game and am very happy with my purchase. Though one could argue it's a little expensive for the kind of game that it is. The brewing minigame is great, and it has lots of cool features and details I haven't mentioned here. But brewing is the entire game, basically. You don't go out to collect your ingredients, there's not much of a story, and you don't really have NPC relationships. I binged Potion Craft for a day when I started, but after that I had to take regular breaks as it got repetitive. Potionomics is a similar game at roughly the same price point with more variety, including a solid card game, lots of NPCs and even dating mechanics.

Currently on chapter 9. This game is a truly amazing take on crafting, and is very fun and unique... but has too many problems for me to recommend it. Mainly, the game expects you to grind a LOT. There is no easy way to do anything in the game for long periods of time. 

You can autocraft, if you have the materials for it. However, theres so many ingredients in the game that eventually, you will not have the materials available for autocrafting. You may think, "so just stockpile on ingredients!" Sadly this isn't possible, as the game is INCREDIBLY stingy with ingredients. You get some freebies at the start of the day, but its never really enough. You can buy some from merchants, but they are unreliable as what they sell you is completely random, and the prices they sell them to you at can be utter bullshit. The game is incredibly unbalanced, to the point of often losing profit from selling potions. 

The lategame progression is also horrendous. There is a massive crafting tree through the alchemy equipment, but to get the final item, you must craft every item several times over with NO AUTOCRAFTING. Not to mention, the late game salts and stones youre forced to craft for progression are nigh useless. In fact, the only useful salts are the first two, the rest of them are overpriced trash only there for you to tick a checkbox. 

One last gripe is the final grind. You could have done everything else in the game and be on chapter 10, and by this point youve served around 500-1000 customers. Around this point youre at probably level 12 or 13. For the final task, the game requires you to get to level 15, which requires you to serve THOUSANDS MORE than what youve already done. The worst part is, this was NERFED. They made the grind HARDER for no reason other for the sake of grinding. Really really poor design choice.

Also, I think the pestle and mortar gave me carpal tunnel.

I am on the fence on this one. On one hand, the gameplay and mechanics are quite creative, and it can be fun and engaging BUT it is weighed down by quite a few downsides :-
1) Early game you have very limited materials to work with, which in turn, limits your ability to explore the alchemy map. Unless you looked up guides to find out where a particular effect is, you won't have enough materials to fulfill your customer's requests, leaving them disappointed and dampening your progress. Not a great feeling.
2) Later in the game, you do have significantly more materials, but at the same time, the recipes you need to make are such a pain. Imagine having to spend 15-30 mins just to make a special potion to serve as ONE of the many ingredients needed to further your progress on a legendary recipe. It feels like work and is so tedious.
3) If you are playing with keyboard and mouse, this game will hurt your wrist. The game requires you to make constant movements with the mouse, such as moving up and down continuously to pound ingredients in the mortar, stirring motion on the pot ladle, clicking repeatedly when haggling, etc. I had to stop playing after a few sessions as my wrist had a persistent ache.
4) The game does a really poor job in explaining the mechanics to you. In order to do well in the game, you have to look up guides or watch playthroughs of more experienced players on youtube. 

On the whole, it is not a bad game. Just very niche and at least for me, can only be enjoyed in short spurts.

An extremely creative game that's lots of fun to play and tinker around in! The use of a map and ingredient-as-pathway for discovering new potions is a stroke of genius and is an unexpectedly natural allegory. Tied with a shop and fairly simple (but not necessarily easy) bartering system, you have several avenues to learn and master this game.

The progression systems are both guided for those who need it, but open-ended, allowing you to do whatever you want and still get rewarded for new discoveries, no matter where you are in the game, provided you have the capacity to make it. The "talent" system for leveling up is another nice way of adding progression. Orders from customers become more complex as you progress, so the game has yet to feel stale. 

The art is beautiful, with a medieval-England aesthetic, albeit with much better rendering than most images that the public is likely accustomed to from memes and the like. The music is a single song, looped, but is chill and fades into the background as you play, being more of an audio backdrop than something you tend to actively listen to.

Overall, this is an amazing game. I would highly recommend playing it!

This game is decent fun for a good run. I've played it for 37 hours at the time of review, and I've been reasonably entertained for most of those hours. 

Pluses: 

- Unique game mechanic - and that counts for a lot for me. Depicting the process of inventing and brewing alchemical potions as a journey around a hazard-lined map is an interesting one, and it allows you to come to a variety of solutions using the materials you have on hand. 

- Pleasantly off-the-clock. Take as long as you like to fulfill a customer request, brew a tricky potion, or discover a new alchemical element. 

- Cozy in a relaxed, tinker-around-with-this way. 

Minuses: 

- It recognizes that you need some sort of save points on the map, but the mechanic is clunky and you often can't save exactly where you want to be - at least, I couldn't see a way to save a position that wasn't a completed potion. 

- After a while, it does get a bit same-y, especially given the lack of non-potion save points. I began to groan when I saw a long-distance brew, and that told me that I was nearing the end of my enjoyment of the game. 

- The tabs system for your potion book is handy, but it gets crowded and harder to use as you brew more potions. Some sort of organization system would be helpful, like second book or whatever.

My best advice is to remember Potion Craft is not an active game like a fighting or adventure game, but much closer to the daily "farming" games you can play for free on the internet. Thankfully, unlike those games Potion Craft doesn't include any up-selling, micro-payments or even a wait requirement. That last can be both a positive and a negative though. 

The game proceeds in days, with each day gaining new plants from the garden to harvest and other resources from peddlers to buy. You are likely to play five to ten days at the start simply to get a hold on everything the game does. However, my advice is:

- Stop playing after every in-game day or two. 

This way you the routine repetition of the game doesn't become monotonous. Potion Craft is fun and can be addicting, just like the online farming games. If you like a game which will slow you down and make you think, Potion Craft is built for you!

Downside
- The game is very static, yet runs at a very high processing speed for my laptop. I don't know if it is because the game hasn't been compiled or still in one of several beta stages. But it looks finished and high polished.

It's quite fun and relaxing to play but feels kinda repetitive after explored all of the maps and potions and becoming abundant in both money and ingredients. Also I know it's meant to be a casual game but I'd certainly like a mainline story to keep me more engaged especially through the late-game instead of making the same stones over and over again in the alchemist machine and being forced by a soul-less chapter books to make useless void salt. Alchemist machine is just PURE tedious and offers no new fun things after you've unlocked everything.

Being forced by a objective book to make those, which I don't technically need to nor do I want to(why would I want to make life salt and void salt?) and getting no real rewards for them makes me feel like my action is worthless. All the NPCs lack agency as well and don't really contribute to the story, nor does my action and choices affect anything. The art style is great and the music and game-play is relaxing. With a better (or rather, any, considering that there's almost none right now) story and mainline objective it has the potential to be really immersive and non-tiring.

Also there's some balancing issue as well. How can a potion with a 180-degree rotation that I spent 500 units of moonsalt to make only worth a couple hundreds more than the level 1 weak version? Moonsalt costs over 20 potions to make so adding moonsalt to any customer-requested potions never made any sense.

Also don't know if's intentional game design or not but the garden is pretty pointless starting from the middle game all the way to the late game. Oil map is also too easy and lacking in new content. Some Really tricky-to-make potion like Luck only sells for a couple hundred meanwhile Necromacy which you can make quite early-on sells for 1200+ before haggle.

WOW, I am so disappointed in this game. As a fan of dorky little sim games, I had been looking forward to this one for a while. I waited for a sale (bless you Steam, or I would have lost even more money on this game) and only paid $8.99 for this but it still feels like an L. 

I'm not entirely sure what the developers of this game were thinking... You have this wonderful idea for a potion crafting and selling game and, instead of focusing completely on the actual crafting part of potions, you tied "crafting" (I use the term loosely here) to a map and exploring said map? And TRUST ME, I hear you when you say "Well wait, crafting but based on map exploration sounds kind of neat!"; I was with you there buddy, trust me, but let me try to explain through a VERY long winded review. Buckle in.

Now let me nip this in the bud right quick: the map is just that, a map. A paper map. A pirate's map. X marks the spot and all. It's cute and it fits with the style of the game, but you yourself do not explore it, and all movement on this map is tied completely to the loose term of "crafting" I'll be using throughout this review. You put your ingredients into the cauldron, be it crushed or not, and then stir to make the potion bottle move across the map. That's the gameplay loop. There are also whirlpools you can choose to move with (they will move you a small distance away) and skeletons/bones(?) on the map that will basically instantly kill you. The crafting happens when you find a bottle on the map and "craft" your potion in that spot. It does not matter the ingredients you put in it to get you there, so long as you got there.
This itself is baffling to me. You created a crafting game where the gameplay loop is move around a map? And perhaps I could see /some/ merit in it if you had to use specific ingredients to even craft the potion when you got to it on the map, maybe? But you don't even need to do that, just any old ingredient that will get you from point A to point B will do. 

And then there's the stuff on the map. Jeez bro, what is with this? Was the map too easy to navigate so the devs had to quickly slap some stuff ontop of it that would diversify the experience and drag out the runtime? Navigating the map already takes ample resources to get from A to B; any you'd like, yes, but ample of them. They all have designated move patters associated with them - one item always goes to the left in a silly squiggly way, while another item will always go right in a silly squiggly way and so on - so you already need to use your resources sparingly and in an optimal pattern to get where you need to go on the completely fogged/hidden map. That's well and fine, and could be a fun way to do things: use an item associated with "wind" that goes in the direction of potions all associated with wind and discover new "wind"esk potions. But... then they slapped these skeletons or bones or whatever the fuck they are onto the map and... they just fail your potion almost instantly whenever your giant potion bottle even slightly touches it? And so what that does is it fails your potion and sends you all the way back to the starting point of the map. All your resources used and all your time wasted. And sure, there's a dilute option that moves your potion a little bit, but all it does is move it back to the start point, so in most situations it isn't helping you. If anything, why not make the dilute move you slightly away from the closest skeleton or fail state or whatever it is? It makes the map extremely hard to navigate because, remember, we only have a few set navigation patters to choose from. It also makes it so, when I need to go around a skeleton, I have to use ingredients that I feel would NEVER be in the potion I am attempting to craft (aka so it will move me in a completely different direction on the map). The whole thing feels counter intuitive and, if that weren't bad enough, they throw more at you on this map! Remember the whirlpools I mentioned earlier? (It's okay if you don't, it's been a minute.) Well they have this neat little ability where they can teleport you to another part of the map nearby. Love that! Makes navigating those skeletons a lot easier right? They're probably designed in a way to help the player, as a mechanic, go in the right direction with less resources. WRONG. It's like I said, the map was designed to be counter intuitive. The whirlpools almost always made me feel like a fool for using them. On the perfect path to a potion and want to see where this'll take you? Assuming it'll be closer to the potion? IDIOT xD! BEGONE INTO THE SKELETON PILE! ..... Like... why? Thanks for the gut punch niceplay. :\ 

Speaking of counter intuitive, what's with that tutorial? I'm sorry but LOL what the actual fuck was that tutorial? You teach the player what a mortar and pestle does and then don't teach us about: the whirlpools, the skeletons, the diluting, the auto-craft feature, the reputation system, haggling, the gifting mechanic, whatever was in the basement idk I refuse to play more to find out, etc. And listen, that's not to say that I didn't appreciate them telling me that crushing the ingredients makes them more potent, but you had a whole text box for what I just said in 7 words and then no tutorial for that entire list I just typed up. Why? You already built the UI for the tutorial boxes and everything, all you had to do was type like 10 more things. I'm about to do a whole lot more typing than those tutorials would have taken and I'm doing it for free just to shit atop your game so like... I think it would have been worth your while.
Meanwhile, the real tutorial of the game is given to you via the quest log. Read what to do, do it, book crosses it out, you get progress toward a perk. It works, but it's just so poorly delivered. The perks are very bland by the way. No idea why that's even in the game. Pressure to have it like other game do? Idk it's boring and useless.

It's like... I want to give this game more credit cause I love the art, music, overall concept, good chunk of the writing, and some of the smaller concepts within the game but.. it's just so hidden by a bunch of annoyances that I can't excuse. 
For example: 
Love having a reputation system, but not only did it take me at least an hour to even realize it was there (because again, no tutorial, never pointed it out) once I did finally figure out it was there and how to make it go up or down I not only didn't understand what the point to having a better reputation was but I didn't understand what was making some sales increase my reputation while some decreased it. For example: I had a pretty bad reputation by the time I noticed it was a thing. I fulfilled all requests that came in and chalked up all the extremely bad requests as just quirky writing and moved on, but found out that wasn't the case and started trying to improve my score and reject people with negative requests. I thought the game might be less black and white about things and I fulfilled some requests that I told myself were "morally grey" and should be allowed. The game did not agree. Okay, that's fine. I will only give the most goodest and neutralest of patrons my beautiful potions. "NAY!" said the game, very loudly into my reputation meter, "-6 YOU FIEND!" The fuck?! The dude had an almost identical request to one that gave me a positive score like 3 customers ago. I don't get it. I just don't.

idk I'm running out of characters and at the end of the day, it's just a game that disappointed me. I just don't want someone that was expecting what I was expecting to waste their money and be sad afterwards. This was 1 of 4 purchases I gave myself for the Steam Winter Sale and I feel a bit cheated with all these lame, overused systems in a potentially cool game. 
Don't get it if you liked my review, get Recettear or We. The Revolution. 
If you hated the review uh... why you still here? Go play the thing.
That's it. Bye.

Despite the general lack of instructions regarding certain things like what whirlpools do and just exactly how those crafting machines work, this game is basically a crafting exploratory game. Explore the map to find unknown potions, figure out how to make those potions with the least amount of ingredients, how to make the highest grade or combined potions and satisfy customers who sometimes make special requests.

Once beyond the main menu, instructions are generally pictorial which can be a bit puzzling. However, a large part of this game is all about exploring and experimenting. All the herbs, mushrooms and crystals have a designated path so being creative in path building to the target is a necessary requirement.

Most strategy is involved with the customers and making money. Though money is not the main focus, it is needed for alchemy machine upgrades, ingredients (herbs, mushrooms, crystals, and especially the much needed potion recipe paper) that need to be purchased. There several merchants that stop by on a regular basis (one merchant per day) who offer specific items. Which items, when, and how much is purchased is all part of the overall game strategy. It is possible to haggle with both merchants and customers (which is explained in-game) but can be difficult for those with slow reflexes. Haggling is not required expect for one chapter list requirement.   

There are ten chapters total, each with a list of requirements to complete. Any requirement from any chapter once completed is recorded. This can be accessed at any time so progress can be tracked. Achievements are game play based and most, if not all, can be achieved while playing. The two reputation achievements are the only ones that need special attention and most likely some grinding.  

Throughout the game play there are progress points earned which can be used to increase money received from customers, increase the rate of map clearance, increase number of level point books and haggling ability.

Highly recommended for crafting buffs especially since there is no grinding needed for progress, only creative thinking. Plenty of crafting to do, lots of exploring needed and enough strategy to keep busy and not be bored. Easy enough for all with focused requirements for progress. Worth the price.

It's funny and cool puzzle game at the start! 
The ingredients decide the way that you play, you move with the ingredients.

In short:
In the beginning you'd be short of cash but especially ingredients. 
Later you'd get some ingredients, but not the ones you actually need. 
Then you get enough of the basic ones. 
Then you'd get exotic ones with weird path which are cool. 
Do you use own imagination with how the potion might taste when you toss in a spicy shroom and couple of hairy bananas... or turd shrooms haha.

So before the 20 hour mark this game is a lot of fun! I think I picked up during a sale when I bought a bunch of crafty choppy games haha. I enjoyed this one a lot.

For the end-game however...
I'm at 40 hours and lingered a lot. I do think the game can be beat, casually, in a shorter play time.
But I have a book full of potions, tiers, and their alternative ingredients, and min-maxed the cost-to-product ratio.

First map dominates 90% of the alchemy ingredients.
Make an ethanol map orso (spirited). Or hot n cold map.

The wealthy (good karma) just want to ''hallucinate'' get ''inspired'' and have ''libido'', Or make a horse go fast so they could win races. And a couple of knights needing copium.
Or fix a broken lock with explosive, I dunno how many time I've sold that potion I ran out of all ingredients, use your imagination about that; either clumsy people, a key stealing elf, or they just want to see a lock go BOOM.

[h1] Supreme Cozy Game [/h1]
If you enjoy the cozy atmospheres of medieval taverns, the pleasure of recipe building and optimizations, and the convenience of a game that can be paused at any moment - don't hesitate to try Potion Craft!

The art for this game is beautiful and the concept is pretty simple - combine herbs to travel around a map and generate potions for customers. In your spare time, buy herbs from merchants and brew potions in the basement to work your way to creating the philosopher's stone! I've had this game for almost a year now, and played it on and off through the year. I will say that it's easy to play this game, but difficult to play [i]well[/i]. I've held my breath more than once as i tipped the water bucket, hoping and praying I create a [b]strong[/b] potion instead of a regular potion. I've scoffed at customers for asking for unreasonable amounts of an herb i don't normally use to make their potion, and I've practically weeped trying to balance my stores of herbs with my insatiable curiosity for those hidden areas of my map. Looking back from the top of the learning curve feels good with this game :)

Even though I've felt satisfied enough with the current features, I'm impressed by the dedication and creativity of the developers. They are hard at work with new mechanics like gardening systems and other fun aspects that I'm looking forward to playing!

[h3] Summary of Review: Get this game and brew all the potions! [/h3]

(depending on personal opinions)

Graphics: Awesome
Very nice graphics. Wonderful style and really suits the theme of the game.

Audio: Great
Pretty good soundtrack. Not outstanding but nonetheless nice, matches the game pretty well.

Plot: Nice
What does exist of the plot is pretty interesting, but it doesn't come up very often. More story would be way more engaging, enjoyable and negate repetition but so far I haven't noticed a lot of it.

Gameplay: Decent
Can get very repetitive at times but it is really fun to mess around with and just do whatever you feel like. Can also be nice as a fairly mindless, chill activity after a hard day.

Themes: Sometimes Mature
Most of the time it is tame, but occasionally you'll get out of the blue s*xual references. There is also implied violence, including domestic violence, and mentions of theft, alc*hol and murder. 

Skills & Benefits: Average
Includes money and haggling, and good strategy when purchasing the resources you need is important, as well as saving your coin. It is pretty effective at helping people lose all faith and trust in the good of human beings.

It can be pretty enjoyable and if it's on a good sale consider it, but it isn't currently worth it at full price.

Maybe I just don't "get" this game, but there is a massive reason I can't recommend it.

The central point is that you explore the alchemy map.  Find new effects, learn how to create all sorts of fascinating potions and then sell them to people.  The problem is, you'd better plan to restart a few times or just use a guide, because if you're poking around the map by tossing ingredients in just looking for something new then you're going to run out very, very quickly.  Really.  Your garden doesn't produce a whole lot each day, you don't have the cash to buy tons of ingredients from vendors even if you work on your trade and haggle skills, and even if you did have the cash their stock is generally small with limited quantities of each item.

If you aren't restarting or using a guide, you will come to a point that you can't produce the potions that people want.  Someone's after a potion to grow plants, but you have only a handful of ingredients to go "east" with.  Now all you can do is tell them to take a hike, costing your store in reputation and fame and not really doing anything to help your ingredient situation - hope you enjoy burning several days just restocking while people spread the news that you won't help customers.

Trying to get Popularity Level 15 is just not fun because at that point in the game you have every recipe for every potion saved and its just clicking through menus. The customers with requirements for potions only make it worse because you lose double the popularity you gain on average by turning them away. So it's just a complete slog. Another annoyance I ran into was through bad RNG I was constantly short on many of the gems that make the high tier potions possible (mostly frost sapphires). My final big late game annoyance was remaking previous alchemy machine salts is just SO ANNOYING. I would have dropped the game if I didn't add a mod that allows you to save the alchemy machine recipes. I understand it's a feature that's intended to be added, but its not in the game now so I can complain about it.   

Hopefully future updates eventually arrive and change my opinion.  

TLDR; Early Game Good, Mid-Game Good, Late Game Atrociously Boring

I find myself remaking a lot of potions just to see what silly ways I can get the result I want, and while sometimes a little tedious with the stirring on long journeys, it's a single minor negative against a lot of positives. I can easily see myself spending 10x the hours I've already put in on this game!

It's a calming game, and I really enjoyed making crazy concoctions to develop potions.  When your potion map visibility improves, you can see the hint of a new potion in the distance.  The journey to get there involves destroying precious resources (if you're less than competent like me) and a mad insane dash, but when you reach it it's beautiful.  I really feel like a crazy scientist with a brand new crazy "invention."

But then there's the "job" part of the game, where you have to remake the same old potions over and over again.  Resource management becomes very important then, and it can get very tedious having to figure out when customers speak in riddles.  A guy who wanted to not be tired won't accept dexterity or swiftness potions, but strength ones instead.  Sure, he came in with a big sword and shield...  But surely a dexterity potion would help him with endurance!

It also seems like the devs have promised a lot of features and updates that just haven't appeared yet.  Granted the game was released less than a year ago so they aren't *too* negligent, I still remember waiting for seven years for Kentucky Route Zero to finish, but it's not that good of a look when a dev promises a lot and doesn't deliver for a while.  Lots of games have stopped updating over the years, makes an end user nervous when another game they kind of like might have the same fate.

All in all, wait for a sale.  It's a fun experience but the "you're a crazy chemist making new potions and tossing resources into the void to do it" and "you're a pharmacist who has to make medicinal potions or rat poison for people while maintaining your stock of ingredients to do it" parts of the game are in direct conflict.  I want to feel more like a mad scientist, not like some burnt out pharmacist who's about to demand that customers just state what potion they want lol

While my review is positive, I do have one major critique of whats there, and possible thoughts, ideas related to it; I'm not sure if the developer will see this positive review, but in the small chance that they might I will offer what I believe is constructive criticism. If your interested in my thoughts, here they are:

If I had to say one bad thing about the game its in relation to the "morality" system in place. Its more of a of a should "I sell to straight up cartoon villains" or should "I sell to regular people." sort of thing, which just feels silly on the face of it.

IMO is its more comical then not. "Got anything I can murder my brother with?" is just not a thing someone is going to ask a random "potion maker"; I understand that the idea is to make it possible to separate the "good" clients, from the villainous ones. But it feels too silly to me to be even remotely believable. Surely they would just ask for "Your strongest poison to take care of a pest problem." right? Otherwise if you were really a good person wouldn't you be calling the guard on them or something?

Actual morality aside, Game-play wise, it functions as a pass/fail system towards moving your shop towards the intended clientele you wish to service. Moving towards "good" takes a long time and making sure you don't accidentally hand anyone trying to kill their nephew poison. Where as you can swing full evil in a fraction of the time by kicking all your regular customers out. I don't know that any specific aspect of this is "bad" but it doesn't feel very "fun" either since most of the time is incredibly obvious if they are villain or not. When its not it feels more like you were tricked by how not obvious that one person was; Though this is my own opinion and therefore not universal.

As it is it just stands out as a glaring disconnect in my mind when I think about the game.

I'd find it more interesting if you could setup a different shop with the entirely separate clientele in mind. Either via two play thoughts where you can select who you want to sell to in the beginning, or some other mechanic... say an after hours back door in the alley way or something. I can see some players choosing to not sell to these villains, while others might want to only sell to them.

The existing system is more or less designed to move towards one of the two extremes anyway, so separating the two client bases might be more interesting if you could maybe moonlight as a villain yourself, since villain to villain this type of overt dialog makes more sense. So it wouldn't be "weird" if simply spoken in a different context.

Or maybe villains could be a "harder mode" as a second play-though, where if they fail to complete their "task", they might seek some form of revenge, say they might come back demanding you pay for your failure to deliver the most potent poison you could. Maybe they rob you, or cause you some other problem like poison your garden for a few days.

As it is the two groups of clients are only different in what specific things they ask for, and there's size-able overlap, and as more clients and requests are added this will likely only become more prevalent if its not paired with other effects. So adding more unique gameplay for villain vs town-person could add depth to the game.

Or dropping morality/villiany entirely, another possibility is to do something like "faction approval" instead. Where you help or refuse service to different "guilds" For instance an example, "thieves guild" might want you to add "slowness" or "sleepyness" to the city guard's night vision potion. This could hurt your relation with the guards, but earn you extra money from the thieves, and good, or bad relations with the guilds might change how many customers you get, and how much they are willing to pay. There's a lot of potential for different interesting, and even small "stories" in this sort of system.

I'm sure there are other options, and possibilities as well, and some of this may not fit very well with the general vibe of the game, so I understand if its entirely ignored; Its not like I sat down to write this after hours of brainstorming and considering all of the game-play considerations, this is truly me just vomiting my thoughts into the review. I guess I'll stop now since I've rambled far too much as is.

I really do want this to be the best version of the the game it can be, because there's a lot to like in here, and I think there is likely some better way to make use of the two different client bases that the game has.

While there are always issues with every game you play, there are some hints and pitfalls a potential player should keep in mind;

- effects on completed potions can *not* be changed when using said potion as a starting point for another, you can only add ingredients to reach the second or third (up to fifth) desirable effect.

- in light of the above mentioned point, it's better to save your desired potion prior to heating thus completing it.  This will allow you to use the "continue brewing" option while permitting changing the original effect's level (assuming you saved the recipe when it reached tier 3 status, downgrading from here is just diluting with the proper fluid), depending on the customer's requirements, before continuing to the final product if there was a requirement of extra effects.

The reason for suggesting saving incomplete recipes that have reached your desired tier is simply to avoid having to create potions from scratch, especially if you need to make something that only required a few extra ingredients and steps to reach... using a completed potion as a base would mean you are stuck with whatever potion you used and chances are you wouldn't even be able to make the desired potion that originally started from a completed potion - result? you have to start from square one having just wasted all the materials to create both the original base and the unusable final product... an expensive mistake if you're running low on the ingredients you used.

Also, by using an incomplete potion recipe as a base, you can skip the extra work required to reach the incomplete base due to the marker being moved instantaneously from the centre to the previously marked point, ie if the potion you need to create was a long way from the centre, an incomplete potion would save you a lot of time & effort depending on the distance (incomplete potion A requires 10 mins to reach, while completed potion B requires 20 mins to reach, or use A to reduce the production time to just 10 mins with less effort required in total)

Potion Craft is supposedly a game where you research an alchemy as you brew potions, gather components, and rebuild an alchemy machine to eventually discover a philosopher's stone.
Potions you craft, you sell to customers, as you gain fame and reputation. That's it - these are two different concept, cause if you sell stuff to bad people who want to do bad things, you will be famous - but [i]differently[/i], you know.
You would also gain experience unlocking skills and improving your craft.
The game is, indeed, drawn beautifully.

However, great concept never found any depth in the implementation. You would see an entire game look in LITERALLY first minute of your game - pick a resource, drop it into bowl, grind it, blow the fire, and may be pour some water - all this to navigate some sort of alchemic map, where potions, obstacles and experience points are located. You may save a recipe, so next time you wouldn't have to do the chore. There is nothing more to the map. Alchemy should have secrets, right? Well, no.
There are some more resources rather than 4 basic ones, but they do not give you any benefit or interesting interaction, they offer you just slightly different path on the map.
Repairing the alchemy machine does not unlock anything either, you just have an alchemy machine repaired, that is all.
Skills are uninspiring, more visibility on the map, more gold from sale, more reputation gain...
But then again, gaining reputation is not really rewarding, come on, more customers per day? Why would I even bother, if I can just start the next day with a click of a button?

All in all, Potion Craft looks very beautiful on outside, but incredibly empty and boring on inside.

This game is a pretty relaxing and chill game, the gameplay loop is very simple but quite complex.

Wake up, get herbs on the garden,answer your customers, make potions they want, close shop, (fiddle around the alchemy map if you have resources), sleep repeat. It's so simple yet very addictive, the best part about the game is crafting the potions themselves.

once you get popularity 5-6 however, your demand will start to increase, and special ways to make potions become available for extra dosh, making new ways to complete the day, and you have to buy herbs and mushrooms from merchants to keep up demand. the game is a lot of fun.

the most complex part about the game is potion crafting itself which is using the right ingredients to navigate the alchemy map and using all your tools to navigate and craft the perfect balanced potion you want,(water to match the potion just right,Mortar&Pistle to increase the effects of your ingredients,Walking inside rift portals to create shortcuts,using crystals to avoid rot camps which will destroy your potion and so on...)

you do have to explore,try and fail to explore the alchemy map yourself in order to find new potions, which means some failures, walking inside rifts that lead no where, and having ingredients that can go in all directions(think of it as a compass) otherwise you can get starved in order to find some potions that are only in a certain direction.

while trading is pretty much very straight foward and simple, its more of a case of [b] you deciphering what the hell your client wants by their anecdote story [/b] and you selling them the right potion. You either sell the potion, or you haggle, which is just a QTE mini-game but Incredibily necessary once you start buying raw materials so you can get a 40-50% off discount on bulk buys.

I find this game to have a unique take on crafting mechanics. So many games have crafting systems (I know that in this game it is technically brewing but shhh) there is one and precisely one way to craft something; one set of ingredients, put into one interface, that normally does the whole crafting process with a single click. This game lets you create, for example, a potion of healing by combining any number of ingredients as long as their total effect lands you in the zone of restoring mana. The game smartly limits your access to ingredients so that you need to forge the same potion but with different ingredients in a different order. This mechanic is the unique mechanic that all the other mechanics and loops of the game revolve around: the experimentation with your ingredients to turn a profit. The haggling and dialogue systems are simplistic but serviceable. There's an entire system of the game that seems like it'll take a lot of time and money to unlock which might be the sign of late-game content.

A fun game about using ingredients to make paths to brewing potions and eventually working towards the goal of every medieval alchemist: creating a Philosopher's Stone. The game loop allows for creativity and a bit of challenge, such as having to use different ingredients to make the same potions at different times, without losing the qualities that make it relaxing. I've also found myself laughing at the array of merchants and customers that appear in my alchemy shop along with some of their requests. Plenty of little references like a nice wink towards fans of several fantasy franchises.

Potions and Chill? What a fun & cozy game.

Potion Craft is essentially a puzzle game. The main gameplay loop is picking ingredients to toss into the cauldron to move the potion around the alchemy map to hit the effects you want to add to your potion. Different ingredients move you in different directions and follow different paths, and you can affect the total distance by grinding them more or less. Ingredients cost money (you get some for free every in-game day) and you need to earn money by selling potions, but the game economy is extremelly forgiving, so you can pretty much do whatever you want. One negative point here is that the game doesn't really change as you keep playing and becomes repetitive after a while. The graphical style is interesting and the music is unremarkable but fitting.

Overall, the game offers an interesting experience and I think is well worth its cost.

An oddly satisfying game. I would absolutely recommend this game as long as you don’t mind a bit of grind. In the game, you run a potion store. You have a little garden, and you spend your time collecting and buying ingredients, figuring out the best way to make potions, and serving customers. It has a laid back pace - you have a certain amount of customers to serve in a day but there’s no time limit on this. You can take your time, experiment, and perfect your recipes. I would recommend this game to exactly 2 (two) types of people. People like me who sincerely enjoy repeating the same task over and over again, not expecting anything to change, but slowly chipping away at clear, if not slow, forward progression. And people who watched the trailer or gameplay, heard the sound that the mortar & pestle make when used, and felt their brain light up with serotonin.

To be absolutely clear, this game can get repetitive very easily, and frustrating at times.

Repetitive in that you're continuously putting the same puzzle pieces in different positions and fine-tuning delicate actions all the time, but also in that after a while... The game just runs out of unique dialogue. Granted, this doesn't happen early, but it does happen eventually. Also, the actual final challenge of the game isn't a puzzle, it's resource-management and logistics. Chaos from even the simplest source can ruin the process and grind all progress to a halt, much like what I imagine a person in the potion-making business would say about potion making. But, y'know, less fun.

Frustrating, in that you absolutely cannot auto-pilot this game. Each action has to be deliberate and thought through, and if you try to take shortcuts it will just re-balance the price and availability of the ingredients in the shop to make sure you don't get any more of that one ingredient that's really good for that type of potion, or that other one that basically just makes the potion for you.

If either of those sound like a horrible time, and not a "Pshaw, I'll get over that" moment, I rescind my recommendation.

However, on the topic of things that could be easily patched after I post this review, the slated updates do promise a way to plant and harvest more of specific ingredients, so that might solve a big issue right there. They could also patch in twice the dialogue, seems probable. But these updates have by now taken seemingly almost an entire year to come to fruition. I'm just saying, if you're looking forward to swift updates and relevant, clear and concise (and most importantly public) communication about those updates, Satisfactory is on this very same store, with a different type of optimization challenge.

Potion Craft has been able to create a really interesting mechanic of crating potions that was challenging, but also fun and interesting! This takes something that would normally be a mini-game within a larger game, and puts it front and centre. The potion making turns into a puzzle and a little journey that you take the potion on in order to make it! But it also makes sure it doesn't wear out its welcome by giving the player ways to save past potion recipes and automatically generate past ones they have made! This makes it fun to try to make the perfect recipe, so the repeated creation of potions never gets bland!

As well as boasting a strong potion making mechanic, Potion Craft also has quite an enjoyable game outside that. There is a nice way to get ingredients, with a relaxing little garden to pick herbs and flowers from, as well as traders you can haggle with. You can also use alchemy to get new ingredients for potions! You run a potion shop where customers will give you hints as to what potion they want instead of outright telling you and you have to figure out the right one. Most of the time it is pretty obvious, but sometimes I just had to guess. Interestingly, some customers will accept different potions and pay more or less depending on how well it fits their situation. You can also get a reputation for giving evildoers potions vs giving regular people potions!

If the gameplay wasn't enough, Potion Craft also has really a really art style, atmospheric music, and really nice feeling controls! The way that you can manually grind, stir and drag ingredients and potions is so satisfying! You can also customise potion recipes and potion appearances! I was surprised that I was able to get 34 hours out of this game, the way it looked, it seemed it would be quite short. If you can ignore the high price, considering it's an indie game, it's quite a fun game to get addicted to for a couple days.

Potion Craft is a good and fun game at the beginning (up to chapter 8) it becomes tedious and boring at chapter 9. 

The concept of the game is really fun, you explore a map for new ingredients and the further you go the more complex your potion will become. After you discover a potion you will try to optimize your recipe by using less ingredients, upgrade to level 3, etc. You will sell this potions in a store and also, in this store, you will be visited by different merchants that will exchange ingredients for gold.

The problem for me comes with the Alchemy Machine. You have to grind complex potions to create stones, that are used to create other stones or different salts. Although you can save the potions recipes in your (really valuable) recipe book, this process is really repetitive and kinda boring. Here is an example: [spoiler]To create Sun Salt you first need to create Nigredo, mostly composed by different tier three potions. Then you will use that Nigredo to create Albedo, with again different potions level three and also a combination of potions with multiple effects. Later, you will take this Albedo to create Citrinas, again, created with the previously mentioned stone and different potions. After this, you can finally create Sun salt, with even more complex potions than before.[/spoiler]

As said, the game is really fun at the beginning but I couldn't get pass the chapter 9, I got bored at the last part of the game. If I had to change something to keep me playing until completion that would be the option for merchants to sell stones and salts.

The game is crazy cheap in my region (less than a dollar) and I had more than 25 hours of fun, only based on that it would be crazy for me not to recommend it.

[i] (Updating my review because of achievement) [/i]
So far, the best potion crafting I have seen in a video game other than mixing/combining X and Y ingredients was in [i] Kingdom Come: Deliverance[/i], where it required a little more effort than that. But even there, you could potentially craft potions watching a video without knowing the recipe. However, in this game you create the recipes yourself by traversing through the map with various ingredients to reach the desired effect, so even if you know where the effect is, you have to manually reach there with the ingredients you have. Despite this unique way of approaching potion crafting and the relaxing gameplay, the game has many issues with balance.
Because you have to explore the map(s) with the ingredients you have, the initial gameplay becomes very slow because you don't have enough ingredients. Furthermore, you cannot experiment enough to find the most efficient recipes, also because you don't have access to all the ingredients. Also, if you turn away customers because you don't have enough ingredients, you lose reputation, and thus less people come to you... it's a vicious cycle. On the contrary, in the late game, you are swimming in money and ingredients, and have no more need to be efficient with your potions, so can afford to waste 5 ingredients for a potion that can be made with one.
It is also funny how as an aspiring alchemist you have no prior knowledge of which potions are on which side of the map. Is Sleep potion closer to Life/Health because it rejuvenates you or closer to Death because it incapacitates you? The character you are playing as doesn't have any clue and may very well be in any other profession unrelated to alchemy.
Moreover, while buying from merchant, the game doesn't show how many of a type of ingredients you have or are using daily in your potions, so your best bet is to buy everything you can afford unless you want to waste a lot of time. There is just no management side of the game, which is a missed opportunity, in my opinion. When you buy new black pages, they get scattered all over the book, so finding and reorganizing them to a side is a painful chore.
The merchants are also not very consistent with their inventory, while customers often tend to ask for similar potions back to back, leaving you always short of certain ingredients, especially crystals. The upcoming Garden 2.0 update might improve the situation, but I am guessing that this dichotomy between early game and late game experience won't be resolved. Maybe a draft mode where you can experiment without losing ingredients until you commit to a recipe will help...

[h1]Potion Craft : Alchemist Simulator[/h1]
5/5 ★★★★★

This game is a great example of inovative game design.
[b]Potion Craft : Alchemist Simulator[/b] strikes a good balance between creative and fun gameplay, puzzle solving, humoristic undertones, and light story-telling.

Grab some ingredients, blend them together to form a path, and explore the [b]Alchemy Map[/b] in search of the potion effects needed to fullfil the requests of your customers. A brilliant mix of planification, optimization, and exploration.

Overall progress is mainly kept through [b]The Alchemist's Path[/b], an in-game checklist, organized in multiple chapters. Each chapter holds set objectives that you must complete in order to progress further into the game, unlocking new customers and new potion requests.

The difficulty of the puzzle aspect does not get in the way of enjoyment or progression, as the player always has the option to "End Dialogue" (i.e. to not fullfil the customer's request) if they do not have the necessary ingredients or if the feasibility of the request is not worth the investment with the player's current saved recipes. However, the player will inevitably have to put in time and efforts to craft the harder and more complexe potions needed to progress the story and the more rare alchemical components.

[b]The Recipe Book[/b] is an essential tool for the player, as it lets you save the recipe of any potion you make, and allows you to quickly craft those potions thereafter, or start from a specific place on the map, eliminating the trouble to plan the more difficult paths again each time the player needs to get to a difficult potion effect on the [b]Alchemy Map[/b].
Furthermore, by progressing and unlocking new ingredients, players might want to revisit their early saved recipes and seek to optimize them, which proves truly useful in making the experience last a little bit longer.

The artistic direction is impeccable, both through the game's distinct and clean visuals, as well as through its very cozy soundtrack. The characters are original and quirky, the ingredients are well designed and come with funny descriptions, and the customization options for the potions you craft (bottles, labels, desciptions, names, etc.) really helps in making the game feel unique.

[hr][/hr]
[strike]There is, however, a big [b]negative[/b].

December 2nd 2022, Potion Craft received the version 0.5.0 major update. With this update, the save files from previous versions became incompatible, as a lot of things had changed both on the [b]Alchemy Map[/b] and in the effects of ingredients. In the patch notes for this update, the developpers said [i]"Previously, we've talked about why save files were incompatible with different versions and why we had to reset the alchemists' progress in the game. This time around, with update 0.5.0, we're going to do it one last time. This version will serve as the foundation for all future updates to the game, which means you will no longer have to start the whole game from the beginning after another major Potion Craft update."[/i]

This announcement did leave some player with a bitter feeling, as it meant they would lose all their progress and need to restart the game from the begining in order to play the final game, but it is understandable given the major changes the game went through during development. Thus, many players started over with a new save file in early december, with the security of knowing that their new game would be compatible with the 1.0.0 version of the game, and that they [i]would no longer have to start the whole game from the beginning[/i].

December 13th 2022, Potion Craft version 1.0.0 officially came out, not without great excitment from us players. But that excitment was cut short for a lot of us when, upon loading in our save file from version 0.5.0, we realized that the Steam Achievments for various objectives in the game did not unlock, despite the requirements being completed. 
This effectively meant that, despite the statement from the developpers, players who began a save file in version 0.5.0 would yet again have to start over to even be able to unlock any of these achievements, which they had already put in the work to meet the requirements for. 
Upon reaching to the developpers regarding this issue, we were given the answer [i]"We are not planning to implement retroactive progress for achievements (at least for now)."[/i]

Needless to say, this left a lot of players feeling bitter and feeling their trust had been betrayed. This alone put a very heavy stain on an otherwise excellent game, and dampened significantly the fun of playing the game, by [i]having to start the whole game from the beginning[/i] anyway afterall.[/strike]


[u]As of December 22th 2022, the achievements have been made retroactive.[/u]



[hr][/hr] 
[b]Potion Craft : Alchemist Simulator[/b] is a genuinely good game, and one that I would strongly recommend to anyone looking for a casual, wholesome, and satisfying experience, and even though the announcements leading to its release were misleading, the team listened to our feedback and it all worked out in the end.

Potion Craft is a game where you brew and sell potions using a variety of tools and ingredients. You progress by exploring the potion map, unlocking new potion effects and interacting with new customers.

The game is relaxing and doesn’t require much focus, meaning it is a good game to play while listening to a podcast or talking to your friends on Discord. The mechanics are unique and intuitive and the game doesn’t hold your hand, allowing you to explore them yourself without looking for guidance online. There is decent attention to detail, the game has an original and appealing visual style and gives you some customisation options which are fun to play around with.

All these traits make the game a very enjoyable experience up to the mid/late-game. That’s when issues start to arise. Eventually you start unlocking less ingredients and effects and the more complex potions take more time and effort to brew. The inventive mechanics start to become tedious and repetitive. The game has 10 chapters, around chapter 8 you will have already unlocked every potion and have a recipe saved for it, unlocked every ingredient and accumulated an abundant amount of it and experienced most unique character interactions in the game. The only things you need to do to progress at this point is complete the remaining special recipes, which create salts that assist with potion crafting. Creating these salts requires you to brew unnecessarily complicated potions which is a cumbersome and not really fun process, and since you likely already have all the potions already available there is no real reason to make these salts other than optimising existing recipes and completionism.

It appears the game is still being developed, although there hasn’t been an update in a long time. In its current state the game is highly enjoyable for the first half, which should provide at least 10+ hours of gameplay, decent for the third quarter but not very enjoyable beyond that. Hopefully future updates iron out the late-game because the game has a lot of potential, and at the moment I would give it a 7/10.

Potion Craft is a unique game in which you craft potions (big surprise!) by using various tools and ingredients. The game's major draw is its detailed animations that occur with virtually every action the player performs, as well as the novel art style. The way the ingredients transform into an impalpable mush or powder with each motion of the pestle, picking up the processed ingredient then physically dropping it into the cauldron, pumping the bellows to add heat to your concoction, manually stirring the contents, and diluting it with water from a sensitive volume-controlled ladle all contribute to a digitally kinesthetic and gratifying experience that keeps the player engaged, and lends generous control on minute aspects of the potion-building process.

After several hours of gameplay, I can confidently say that Potion Craft, in its current state, is a high quality, polished product, but does leave a bit to be desired, as eventually one will have experienced much of what the game has to offer. But considering the game is in early access and the developers seem to be coddling their product and listening to the community's feedback pretty well, there seems to be hope for a much more indulgent experience down the pipe in the future, which has me optimistic. For now, I have faith that Potion Craft is a great foundation for whatever the developers have in store for the future.

A very good game for the price, relaxing but weirdly engaging at the same time.

I started to feel that "Zen" level of concentration that comes from other activities like playing an instrument, working with tools... or practicing an actual trade, which is what I felt like I'd learned by the time I finished playing. The game recreates that realistic vibe through the physical experience of using your lab instruments. You can stir rapidly or slowly, but with the movement of the mouse and the animation onscreen it's easy to forget that you're not actually stirring. You can pulverize ingredients methodically or even violently with your mortar and pestle, but again, the translation of mouse movement into onscreen action gives a sensation like you're actually working in your own laboratory.

Things start out simply enough, and the mechanical underpinnings of the game stay pretty much the same, but challenge and complexity continue as you progress through the game. This comes from a few different factors. Initially, there's a scarcity of effective ingredients to work with. As you progress further, your toolbox gets bigger but your objectives on the alchemy map get more and more difficult to reach. And as all of those pieces finally fall into place, the game generates new novelty through the sometimes-exacting specifications put forward by your customers - combinations of effects, including/excluding certain ingredients, limiting the number/type you can use, etc.

By the time I got to the VERY end of the game and picked up the last couple of achievements, I kinda just wanted it to be done with... But, then again, there are so many games in my library that I never 100% finish because I feel like it's not worth attaining for the level of effort involved. This was within reach, so I went for it, and I certainly enjoyed all of the hours I put into the game short of maybe the last 2-3 that I did just for the sake of being a completionist. Maybe there's some room for improvement in the gameplay loop all the way toward the end of the game? Either way, I'm not too concerned.

Maybe my only other complaint is that Potion Craft has ONE single music track on a perpetual loop - listening to a 2-minute loop for 30 hours can be tough to manage in large doses. But they've mentioned that that's something they're already working on, so by the time you pick up the game and get to the 10-hour mark maybe your head won't be ready to explode and you won't need to take a day to cool off.

Overall, I enjoyed my time with the game, and I plan to revisit it once they add some of the new features they've hinted at. But that's not to say that Potion Craft doesn't already feel complete in its current state. It was fun, it will be the next time I pick it up, and I feel perfectly fine recommending it at the full price listed.

On a side note... If you like dark humor, feel free to start catering to some of the more questionable people who visit your establishment and asking you to do questionable things. I got a good laugh out of some of the ridiculous explanations customers gave me for a bunch of their potion requests.

I bought this game in early access, and game is fun, or at least is for the first few hours when you're learning everything. However the grind is real, it's REALLY real. Trying to get all of the achievements for this game was genuinely a painful affair. I mean that literally, as the amount of potions you make and the amount of ingredient grinding and stirring can lead to some mouse hand fatigue. There is very little guidance throughout the game, and lots of time saving features are completely hidden, I only discovered them nearly two dozen hours in the game.

You spend A LOT of time just doing repetitive movements. Heating up the cauldron speeds up your potion's travel time across the map, but also activates the teleportation whirlpools so you're better off with the glacial default travel speed. The game also never tells you that right clicking your completed potions and ingredients automatically adds them to the customer scale and mortar & pestle respectively. Later in the game when you have dozens and dozens of ingredients with hundreds of quantities of them, not having any sort of user friendly read function besides hovering your mouse over them is incredibly time consuming and irritating.

There are a few typos in the customer requests as well, while not debilitating, it does take you out of the life sim the game markets itself as. In general you're just grinding for RPG elements that just add a % increase to what you had already in the game. With the exception of your first alchemy machine project, the entire game can really be boiled down to only a handful of very repetitive actions. If you play this game for 2, maybe 3 hours, you've already experienced everything it has to offer- just with slight deviations.

After you finish your first Nigredo, Albedo, Citrinitas, Rubedo, and finally your Philosopher's Stone, you realize that they're really just further ingredients to make the various alchemy salts. However, you only really need moon salt, so you just make 5, maybe 6 of those and you don't have to bother making Sun Salt, Life Salt, or Philosopher's Salt. As you only need one type of these to rotate your potions to the correct angle, and Philosopher's Salt comes so late into the game that you should have hundreds of any ingredient you require to make any potion you'd wish.

Adding onto that, the very last alchemy machine potions are just effects separated by one side of the map to the other. I understand that this is a simple system, but it's just time-padding plain and simple. This game could have been very nuanced with a lot of complex customization features. You could have combined potions to make potion tiers above 5, or utilized your alchemy machine ingredients into super expensive panaceas that could net you the thousands you need to get your alchemy stashes stocked up and ready for the final projects. I also have to imagine that the 10,000+ ingredients really fit into your tiny medieval alchemy shack, and that you're not some time traveling Bezos slave peddling Amazon snake oils to medieval peasants. 

Overall, There's a very fun essence and art style to this game, someone poured their heart and soul into the art style and it does feel thematically accurate. I just feel like it's half baked and a time sink without the level of depth that it first appears to. I hope that it has some updates, but from reading the other reviews, I believe this game was really released before it was totally finished and just labelled as such to move onto a different project. Buy it on sale, I bought it when it was $10 in early access, I'm sure it will dip this Christmas and you can spend 40 hours playing this instead of hugging your family or something.

Producing the stone isn't quite a simple task and at first glance it shines completely unbearable. After some playing done, the player starts to recognize most of the patterns and required tactics to solve the thing and that's where it hits the head with the hammer - there is a layer upon a layer in a layer, where you have to make it all by hand with quite an overwhelming width to it.

Nevertheless, I still do recommend the game - it brings lots of joy while it lasts.
