This non-recommendation is to inform the developers that I don't think some of their ideas for increased difficulty are realistic or fair to the player. Adding conditions like "I only want a potion with 1 type of ingredient" is not just unrealistic, it's unfathomable that anyone other than a mage or alchemist would come with such a request, and realistically, they probably wouldn't make such an utterly ludicrous stipulation either. The requests to avoid or include a specific ingredient are much more realistic and understandable. Any limits on the number of ingredients are just silly. How is a bloody peasant supposed to KNOW what's in the love potion you just offered them? How are they supposed to KNOW you didn't just give them a health potion? The game uses some direct logic that defies the reality that most of your customers wouldn't be able to discern the effects of your potion until they actually take it.

And the hits to reputation are silly as well. If I refuse service to some idiot who comes in and DEMANDS a potion with only 1 ingredient AND multiple effects and refuses anything that doesn't meet those IMPOSSIBLE criteria, why should I get penalized for telling that customer to go somewhere else? And at higher rep levels, the hits should be LESS, not more. Because your reputation is STRONGER, the complaints of a single person should mean LESS. Here's the simple logic, as your reputation increases, more of the populace will have been your customers and also had good experiences, thus the effect of a dissatisfied customer's complaint will be dismissed by the greater balance of good experiences. This effect would naturally increase as your reputation level increases and customers beyond your town also carry word further.

It might make more sense if these complications were tempered against your trading skill, which at this point doesn't help you much except to acquire gold a bit faster. It would also make some sense that you could haggle a customer down on their requirements, like instead of 1 ingredient, you could haggle for 2, or 3 depending on your skill.

And why is everyone demanding poopshroom when it hasn't even been offered for sale and I've literally never even acquired it? Why are customers demanding impossible criteria that my only option is to refuse? Just for more artificial difficulty?

[h1]TL:DR[/h1]
Релиз - скам. Игра не доделана, но играть можно. Настоящий релиз будет позже, тогда лучше и стоит покупать игру.  Без необходимых доработок  игра выглядит так: начало - молитва рандому, чуть дальше - есть деньги, но сидишь без необходимых ресурсов и еще чуть дальше - ты и есть казна, и это по прогрессу где-то на 25% от всей оставшейся игры.
___
[h1] Предисловие [/h1]
Вот это да. Вот это они меня удивили. Вышло обновление 0.5 второго декабря, думаю, дайка сейчас нормально засяду за игру. Прохожу потихонечку, а тут бац - выкатывают 1.0, aka релиз игры. Посмотрел изменения - 1.0 минимально отличается от 0.5 и НЕТ многих необходимых игре фич. Куда они торопятся? Это маскировка под релиз, никак иначе. Воспринимайте так.
Самое забавное, что они понимают недостатки игры: описали, что будет в будущих обновлениях, и их часть касается моих претензий. Но, блин, эта часть должна быть в релизе... Зачем они так сделали? Не ясно. Если бы ради денег, т.к им не хватает по какой-либо причине, то кроме выхода в релиз могли бы цену изменить. Нормальная практика. Хотя они могли себя в капкан поймать, когда  мб заранее написали, что цена на игру не изменится после релиза- тогда понятно. Пока эта плашка с информацией Early Access была - не вчитывался.

[h1]Cписок незаконченных моментов из-за чего игра должна находиться в раннем доступе[/h1]
	> [b]Сад[/b]. Это вообще что такое, зачем это игре в таком виде. Сад дает тебе рандомное количество рандомных ингредиентов. Контроля там абсолютно столько же, сколько в спальне главного героя, а именно 0. По ходу игры ты понимаешь насколько было бы лучше и правильнее, если б алхимик мог настраивать сад под текущую задачу или ситуацию в инвентаре.
	> [b]Скиллы[/b]. Скучные? Определенно. А еще это то, что позволяет сломать экономику игры довольно быстро. Дальше будет гайд. Вы предупреждены: [spoiler]Парочка очков в быстрое прокачивание навыков -> Экспертная сложность -> Все в торговлю почти до конца ->  открываете пятую сложность торговли (если уже есть проблемы на 4, то пропускаете этот шаг) -> качаете до конца торговлю. Может есть куда оптимизированный путь прокачки, но даже этого хватает[/spoiler]. А самое смешное в том, что ломать не особо-то приходится. В начале, да, проблема с деньгами есть и ты не можешь все скупать, поэтому берешь только то, что тебе нужно или если это не самое начало, а час игры, то все, что с низкой ценой. Но потом ты можешь все скупать и у тебя всегда остаются деньги. 
	> [b]Торговцы[/b]. В контексте предыдущих пунктов это прям провал. Если то будет доделано, то лично я с торговцами смирюсь. Почему у них ассортимент настолько рандомный и неясный? Было бы здорово, если бы, например, торговцы в определенные дни недели продавали бы какой-нибудь процент, например, огненных ингредиентов и все оставшиеся % ветряных. А так, получается, что ты вроде как имеешь деньги, а необходимого из раза в раз нет

[h1]Послесловие[/h1]
Исправление всего вышеперечисленного игроку  планировать свои дальнейшие действия куда лучше и естественнее, а не полагаться только лишь на рандом по большей части, не считая центральной комнаты. Вы сами написали в названии Achemist Simulator. Давайте вспомним матчасть - как устроены другие симуляторы. Они предоставляют часть реального мира в мельчайших деталях в конкретной выбранной тематике игры. В Euro Truck Simulator система прокачки простая, да и управление рабочими тоже, но это не вредит основному геймплею. Суть игры - в перевозке грузов, тебе не нужно обращать внимание на все остальное с такой же подробностью. Без разницы сколько твои наемные рабочие получают, неважно насколько у тебя прокачен навык на дальнюю дистанции - все это, еще раз, никак не влияет на перевозку грузом: какой был геймлуп в начале, таким и остался в конце. В данном случае наш текущий подопытный отличается. Т.к игра берет тематику не из нашей реалии, то приходится полагаться на общее представлении об алхимиков. Алхимики - варят зелья. С этим игра справляется, но ведь у нас не бесконечный приток ресурсов для них. И выходит, что вне варки мы должны заниматься получением ингредиентов. Не рандомно, а обдуманно, т.к это неотъемлемая часть геймлупа игры. Не нужно упрощать процесс вашим волшебным деревом в саду, которое каждый день дает ресурсы. Это дешево и несерьезно. С одной стороны упростили, с другой - убрали глубину, которая этой игре выходит нужна

[h1]Пример из игры[/h1]
И теперь вкупе со всем описанным вот вам доп. материал. Типичная ситуация после двух-трех часов игры: ты скупал все или почти все у торговцев (потому что игра позволяет это легко сделать буквально через пару часов), начинаешь новый день, смотришь с какой проблемой пришел посетитель, понимаешь какое зелье ему подойдет, пытаешься сварить и оказывается, что ты не можешь этого сделать, т.к в ту часть экрана ни один ингредиент не идет. Только представьте как бы это легко решалось с персонализированным садом: заранее мог бы посадить ингредиенты, которые скоро закончатся и все, твоя проблема решена
---
[h1]Итог[/h1]
Все, я излил душу. Надеюсь, хаос в обзоре ясно объяснил мою позицию. Игра хорошая, вы не подумайте. Но это не релиз. Само собой, когда исправят все выше перечисленное - подправлю обзор . А сейчас мне сложно назвать эту игру  [b]симулятором[/b].

I LOVE this game. It's such a great time killer, and I love potion making. I think the potion map is a great way to have people make their own recipes, and I love the variety of ingredients there is. I'm very excited for future updates, especially regarding the garden.
One of my favorite features in this game is the recipe book! You can buy pages from the wizard and just have a HUGE recipe book. By the end of my first run (~55 hrs) my book was FULL. I just think its so fun making new recipes according to the amount of ingredients you have. The artstyle is also very charming, it looks like its right out of a medieval book or something. 
I will say this:
If you don't like repetition, this game is NOT for you. I love the repetition, grinding up plants and ESPECIALLY crystals is very satisfying for me. You WILL be doing a lot of things over and over for the story progression, because to progress you need to make multi-effect potions for the chapters. I think it's really fun because you need to strategize what direction you go in first, in order to make the most cost effective potions for your crystals and salts.
All in all, I think this game has a lot of love and effort put into it! If you want to be a potion maker and merchant, this is the game for you!

Sometimes it seems potion games are a dime a dozen, but Potion Craft stands out with quite the unique way to mix and make them. You have an alchemy map (I assume in our minds) and with its help you navigate and discover recipes. Each ingredient has a set motion path on this map, which can be manipulated by mashing the ingredients and adding more water. The result is a game about trial and error in attempts to create the most efficient recipes to necessary potions. Though you can skip the tedium with typical brews; you always have the option to save the recipe to quick brew later or continue to create and refine your potions from scratch.

I almost liken it to home cooking. Many cooks do not measure, they taste and judge as they cook. I can only assume we are doing the same in this game, knowing certain ingredients do certain things we want and adjusting the brews as they develop. Further, the more you make them and the more new ingredients you discover, you find substitutions and shortcuts to refine your recipes just like home cooking.

All in all, it is interesting and fun. That said, tier 3’s and multi effect potions are a pain (at least getting them efficiently) and currently your ingredients are fairly RNG based. It can be a bit frustrating if you hit a wall, but there are no time constraints that punish you for waiting until you can easily surmount it. It is worth a try if any of this sounds appealing.

Here's how the game works: There's a board with things on it which you want to get. Each time you craft you start in the middle of the board, different ingredients make your piece move on the board in different ways. That's literally the whole game, you are now a potion crafting master. When I picked up the game I was hoping to see some interesting mechanics, there aren't any.

You can make your own judgement of the visual style; however, what animations there are, are very limited. So I'll give it a 2/10. Two points for successfully making a game that works. They explored the boundaries of minimal effort and investment. It would be more at home on a cellphone.

Potion Craft is a great relaxing game.  As many have said, it can get a bit grindy and boring when you hit a lull in progression.  Some of the negative comments have been about the lack of specific resources available for harvest/purchase when needed.  I think the reason for that discouragement is the misconception about the game's genre.  At it's heart, Potion Craft is a puzzle game more than anything else.  Figuring out how to reach specific potion effects without the ideal ingredients is part of the fun early in the game.  Later in the game, you may have better ingredients, but not the ones you have used in saved recipes.  That forces you to revisit some of the easier potions to try for better efficiency.  

This game is definitely not for everybody, but I think it's definitely worth a look for people who like puzzle games.  I wholeheartedly agree that it needs some more exploration and maybe more world interactivity.  Upcoming updates with Talents 2.0 and Garden 2.0 look perfect for that.  I'd love to see some actual adventuring to gather ingredients, meet customers that become regulars, etc.  That might taint the allure of this game's simple relaxation, however.

Look up some videos on gameplay before you buy, but don't go too deep.  The exploration and discovery is a good chunk of the fun!

I very rarely recommend a game before I beat it, but this one has really grown on me in such a short time, that I didn't feel it would be right not to put out a review for it.

Potion Craft is a relaxing game where there are no major time limits and this gives you full freedom to come up with creative and innovative new ways to problem-solve in the game. I am over halfway through the game's story by now, and it still feels like I am learning new tricks and workarounds, coming up with my own creative solutions for the problems I face daily. So far I've discovered like, twenty something different kinds of potions and I haven't explored the map fully yet. You can even mix and match various potion types if the situation will allow for it.

The basic gameplay loop is simple enough to get used to quickly. You run a potion shop and collect your ingredients from the garden to begin your day, and then open up the shop for customers. Each customer has a need for a potion that will complete a specific task - but there is often more than one solution to the same problem. You get a recipe book to save really useful brews to recreate on-demand. Merchants will also start visiting your shop after awhile, and they will become your primary means of replenishing your supply of various ingredients. 

In-between fulfilling orders and trying to work mysterious machines needed for the plot, you will have time to explore the Alchemy Map, making this game more similar to an open-world dungeon crawler of sorts. To be fully honest, I'm not entirely sure how best to categorize this game. All I know is, it's definitely found its way onto my favorites list rather quickly.

A new update is going to drop sometime soon that will entirely revamp the Garden and Talents, but so far it seems to have plenty of game in here as it is. If you need something less action-packed that will still work those mental muscles, Potion Craft is a good one to pick up.

I used to recommend this game but am changing my review.

In the Demo and Early Access we were promised many features that have still as of "release" not made their way into the game. They still say these features are coming but it has been 9 months since the last major update and all we have seen is dev logs. If the game were in a "finished" state I'd be fine with this but even in their most recent dev log they stated that the current system used for level ups is a "place holder" for what they really wanted. That means we are still playing Early Access and this whole experience has felt like promises were made but not kept.

This is a chill and novel experience but gets stale quickly. The endgame is mostly devoid of meaningful content and requires an absurd amount of grinding to complete the "Alchemist's Path" (the main progression system in the game) to the point where 1% of the players who own the game have actually completed it (and really, completing it is not hard; it will just take a shift's worth of clicking "sell" to get there).

In the last update (almost a year ago now) we saw a new potion base added (something that had been promised in the Demo and EA) which gives you a new map to explore. Sounds great! The catch: it is significantly smaller than the first map and pretty much only serves to give you a tool to use back on the main map. There weren't even potions on that map that you couldn't find on the original map; just the same potions (not even ALL the same potions) with a shorter distance to get to them (and a different rotation angle that you have to reach to make a "tier 3" potion). What is the point then? This seemed like a pretty gift filled with air; just another way to spend time doing the same thing with very little to show for the effort.

I really was enamored by this game initially but with how much was promised and the fact that 1.0 came and went without the majority of these promises being met means to me that the dev team might just get tired of working on this and move on and there is no accountability for them to follow through on the things this game originally told us would be in here.

I hope to come back and change this review again down the line but until then I will say that "release" felt like a cash-grab/lie and hope that this team delivers on the promises made to the people who invested in them the first week of EA.

This game is worth playing, but don't expect to play it very long until they expand on the gameplay loop. It is about experiencing what a nice crafting system could be. What would essentially be a simple side-minigame in another MMORPG, has been purified to it's concentrated form and expanded into a full game in here. Unfortunately, for now I find the game "finished" at around mid-game. Everything later than that seems like a more tedious repetition of the the exact same routines. I feel it lacks on a story-wise and the puzzle-wise front. Nevertheless, developers are constantly working on it and posting devlogs, so we will see how it goes. IIRC I bought it on sale, and for that I am grateful -- the game earned for itself. If I had bought it at it's regular price, however, I could have been underwhelmed and disappointed. This game works as a prototype or art form, but to be a fully-fledged, 100% completable casual title it needs some serious core gameloop improvements. Nonetheless, I am happy that I experienced this piece, thus I recommend trying it out... but at the same time -- maybe wait for a sale, or for some major patch first.

Pros:
- Unique and simple mechanics which are fun to play and mesh well together
- Beautiful art and meticulously crafted details shine brightly in this game
- Calm and serene atmosphere without any pressure of time and without inducing a fear of missing out
- Mechanics are generally intuitive, assigning one of 8 attributes corresponding to the ingredient gives this game another layer of depth
- UI and UX are very good, it is just a pleasure to interact with this game

A room for improvement:
- For a game that you most probably spend long time playing during one session, the diversity and amount of music is very lacking. At times it even makes me dizzy listening to the same music on a loop, which forces me to either close the game or mute it. For example dwarf fortress has 18 or so, minecraft has 2(3?) albums while this game, for now, has only 2 very similar tracks.
- It has (a bad type of) grind at times, and from what I have heard and experienced already, the it's even more severe mid-to-late game. Several repetitive in-game days often pass by without much progress and doing essentially the same thing over and over, crafting the same potions but varying the ingredients from time to time, only to wait for a specific merchant to bring you a new part for the alchemical or none of the ingredients you lack the most. I Definitely didn't reach end-game. Maybe I tapped onto the front doors of the mid-game, but for now it gets quite repetitive. I have not unlocked the new alchemical map -- I got tired of doing the same thing over and over.
- It feels claustrophobic at times as well. Seeing the fields outside the windows makes you want to go outside and explore the world. Seeing the bedroom makes you want to interact with it, but it's essentially a whole screen added for the sake of one and only interaction - the bed to skip a day.
- There is a purely cosmetic mechanic of the reputation that has no real gameplay impact, but it has a yet untapped potential.
- There are several places where you can progress, but they feel a bit disconnected. The Alchemist's path feels a to be of little importance and not very impactful. I Breezed though 4 pages (almost half of the book) in one (6h?) sitting almost without noticing it. Talents are a bit weirdly distributed in time: you can reach level 28 and learn >50% of all the talent levels in the first sitting. I guess final levels are the hardest to get, but if not, You may be wondering layer "what now?". I see they have plans for new talents so I'm looking for that and maybe some more improvements on that system.
- Haggling is something that you almost always want to do, so there should maybe be some balancing on that matter. 
- Performance: for a game that moves around a bunch of sprites, it has a surprisingly high impact on the my machine. From the simplicity of the machanics and graphics I assumed this game could be played on a toaster. but it felt a bit sluggish at times and ventilators start working considerably louder. I also don't understand the very long load time, somehow? It uses 2.2 GB when in background (on Linux Proton), 85 vt-threads and 20% processing power of a 6 core processor? How?
- There seems to be a lot of content (look at all those potion stickers!), but it's quite inaccessible due to the grind. I find maps to be a bit too big, the trips of potions too long and the lack of different starting points tedious. Maybe if there was some way to move the potions larger distances it would be better. For example some kind of pressure mechanic - when brewing under pressure, the whole map would shrink (or the ingredient path would expand) allowing for travelling bigger distances quicker?
- Alchemical machine is underwhelming. After using it you are left with "...was that it?"

My ideas for growth:
- It would be nice if the potions crafted in the game had some more uses. A good example is the upcoming feature of the wild growth potion for plants. Crafting a potion of fire or a potion of cold is essentially the same thing but using different ingredients. It would be nice seeing some real impact those things have on the world around us. Libido/love potion could affect bees which would in turn pollinate flowers, or increase a chance of random plants growing. A Potion of strength could be used to break a broken door for the inaccessible part of the house (or the city, read below). A slowness potion could be used to increase the accuracy of using tools, while a speed potion would amplify the effects of paths or something
- If the alchemical machine was more interactive, it could give another dimension to the game. Twisting corks to mix potions in right proportions, pouring out the sludge or sediment from vials, heating and keeping mixtures at good temperature for a certain amount of time, adjusting angles of tubes, lighting up flames and adjusting their height and strength, connecting the tubes, releasing or increasing the pressure and whatnot are some of the examples I would think about adding if I were a part of the team. Maybe instead of buying whole sets of alchemical machines we would buy flasks and components which we would later combine and place on our own? Managing space and using available tools?
- There is an untapped potential of discovering the world's lore while progressing through the game and feeling like a part of the a living universe. Merchants could bring books or tell tales. We could buy paintings of distant lands or explanations of the origin of plants etc.
- There is a place for a story about the mystery of the alchemical cottage and it's previous owner, which we would progressively unravel. Rooms we could unlock, repairs we could make, notes and bits of knowledge from him etc.
- It would be very nice to see some more locations. A city or a village, a cave, a forest, a tavern, a castle and whatnot could be added. Different shops in the city to make use of the earned money and use the potions to interact with NPCs in there. See them walk around and do their things. Haggle for tools with villagers, use strength potion to break the doors of a closed abandoned shop, use potion of nightvision to access a cave, Combine it with the reputation mechanic to make some locations more accessible or restricted than others, for example bad reputation would prevent you from interacting with rightful shop owners but would in turn give you access to the backalley and black market, where you could buy some exclusive forbidden items. With good reputation you could buy certified exclusive goods from good merchants etc.

Ultimately this game is constantly growing, and planned features will probably resolve some of the issues mentioned above, so I'm only looking forward to it! The above critique doesn't impact my positive reception of this game, and I still highly recommend playing it.

A pleasant casual game where you make potions for customers.  There are only five screens in the entire game so it's pretty self-evident what the game is about.  There are no time limits or meaningful limitations so you can take it at your own pace.  The main mechanic of finding potion effects by tracing paths along a map using different ingredients is engaging enough, and recipes can be saved so you don't have to repeat the exact same thing over and over.  There is no story, so you kind of just play as much as you want until you're satisfied and stop.  For me that was at about the 25h mark.  That said, I wanted to be completionist about it, so I powered through to make all the (rather unnecessary) alchemical substances and get all the achievements; this took 40h.  Making all of the complex potions to get to that point was actually very tedious and I had to pace it out over many disparate play sessions, but there's no reason to feel this is mandatory - it's only there if you want to keep playing.

I really wanted to like this game - I was drawn to the simulated act of picking plants, grinding them, adding them to my cauldron, and selling potions to customers. But I noticed a sharp drop off in the Steam achievements, with about 50% of players completing chapter 1 of 10 and 1% of players actually finishing the game. I imagine that most people drop off because unfortunately, a lot of the game is a repetitive grind. Pretty much my biggest problem with it is that it feels. so. repetitive.

The game started out great, beautiful artwork and fun mechanics. I enjoyed exploring the map. But then I learned that exploring the map consumed materials rapidly, especially as I traveled further from my starting point - which, by the way, is the same no matter what. You always start at the same point in the map, and by mid-game, you have traveled over the same areas over and over again. It was fun to fulfill requests at first, but then they became repetitive too. Unlocking alchemy seemed promising and I was hopeful as I created the first materials (Nigredo), until it turns out that it just requires the same gameplay but with even more grinding. Now I don't mind grinding when I think the effort is worth it, but this game didn't offer enough "newness" to keep me engaged.

Another problem I have is with inventory. I never have enough of a particular plant, which is alright - that's what vendors are for! Except you have no guarantee that any particular vendor will be available when you need them. Which is still alright as long as they appear often enough - except most of the time the herbalist or mushroom guy aren't carrying what I need! My garden will not stop giving me more of a plant that I already have 100+ of, but yields like 3 of another plant that I have 0 of. Lack of control over inventory (being unable to grow or buy what I need even when I have the gold) contributed a lot to my frustration.

Overall, this is a game for some people who enjoy the gameplay loop, and I still think the early game is fantastic. It just didn't have much to offer me past the first few hours.

Potion Craft is a game where you play as an aspiring alchemist who runs a shop in a medieval town. You have to mix ingredients, brew potions, haggle with customers, and manage your finances. Sounds fun, right? Well, not so much when you have to deal with the most annoying and demanding customers ever. They want potions for everything: love, health, beauty, strength, invisibility, you name it. And they’re never satisfied with the price or the quality. They’ll complain, bargain, threaten, and even try to rob you. And don’t get me started on the ingredients. You have to gather them from the forest, the swamp, the mountains, and other dangerous places. You have to dodge traps, monsters, bandits, and angry villagers. You have to spend hours grinding them, boiling them, stirring them, and hoping they don’t explode in your face. And you have to do all this while keeping track of your recipes, your inventory, your reputation, and your competitors. It’s exhausting!

Potion Craft is a game that will test your patience, your creativity, and your sanity. It’s also a game that will make you laugh, cry, and rage quit. It’s a game that will make you feel like a real alchemist, for better or for worse.

 Would recommend to anyone who likes a challenge, repetitive gameplay, and a good sense of humor.

[b]Potion Craft[/b] realizes the fantasy that everyone had at least once about living a laid back and simple life in a fantasy/medieval setting.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game is very simple, harvest ingredients, brew potions, sell them to various customers and buy better ingredients to brew yet more powerful/refined potions that it’s incredible no one else made a game around such a simple gameplay loop.

A highlight is as expected the potion making aspect of the game, the brews don’t require a specific thing to make, instead here each component moves a little potion icon on an alchemical map in a certain pattern to reach the desired effect.

The game keeps itself fresh for a little while, adding components crafting which require certain potions with multiple effect to them, discovering the brewing process and optimizing it for each potion, and a haggling mechanic to get some more margin when buying/selling stuff.

[h1]Story[/h1]
It consists only of recurring characters showing up from time to time but besides a few snippets of information nothing of importance is really going on, no overarching plot or seething, nothing.

[h1]Downsides[/h1]
Unfortunately, it becomes really stale really quickly to the point where I felt completing the game was more of a chore than anything else.

[h1]X-Factor[/h1]
However, the developers have announced multiple additional features that’ll keep the game from being boring once it’s going to be updated.
[hr][/hr]

Potion Craft is a simple game to learn but there's depth to navigating the potion map with efficiency and grace. Advancing through the game is an excellent balance of unlocking in-game skills/equipment while always requiring the actual player to be diligent and skilful in their crafting. It really does make you feel like you're exploring the natural-magical properties of these fantastic herbs, mushrooms, and minerals. 

Though the game feels like it could easily be expanded to include more shop management, herb foraging, even quest-like aspects, as a stay-at-home dad I also really appreciate that the simplicity of Potion Craft means it can be picked up and put down with ease. Perhaps some optional DLC could allow the casual players to keep it casual but allow the detail-driven players to add features. 

Either way, Potion Craft's aesthetic and game play are both so delightful, I heartily recommend!

So... This is a maybe.  Not a recommend, but I didn't have that option.  To explain my complaints, I have to explain how this game works.

There are five separate screens, each with its own purpose: a workshop in which to make potions, your store, your back garden, your basement (presumably for those people you really don't like), and your bedroom.  The bulk of the gameplay occurs in the workshop and the store.  So... what do the other rooms do?

The bedroom is where you advance to the next day (that's it...).  The back garden will produce a crop of alchemical ingredients once per day.

And it's with the garden that I have a problem.  You-the-player have absolutely no control of which plants will spawn there.  This is a problem because if you have several people show up requesting the exact same kind of potion, you can easily run out of ingredients (especially if there are only two or three of a given direction in the morning).  A system where you can plant seeds to ensure you get certain plants is sorely needed.

The actual gameplay is great.  To brew a potion, you must choose an ingredient (which can travel across the map in a set path), prepare it, add it to the potion, stir the potion, repeat.  There are obstacles on this map to avoid.  To complete a potion, you must boil your cauldron close to an effect node.  The node determines which effect you get, and your proximity to it determines the potion's strength (on a scale of 1-3).  All of this is explained in the tutorial, which is very helpful.

In your shop, you sell the potions you brew and can buy ingredients.  But be cautious, if you sell poisons to unscrupulous sorts, you'll gain a reputation (and customer base) befitting an evil alchemist.

This is a very relaxing game and has a lot going for it, but the complete lack of control over what ingredients are in stock makes progress VERY (read: EXTREMELY) frustrating.  

Anecdotally, I had six customers across two days all request stone-armor potions, and I could not use the same recipe more than twice because I kept running out of ingredients.  That's in addition to the Stone Armor potion I needed for the project in the basement.

The basement... I'll be honest.  I have no clue why the basement is there.  Supposedly you can make things down there, but they don't seem to have any use and are a real pain to complete.

This game is a mixed bag for me. 

Pros:
On the one hand, it's meditative and completely predictable, which I like - vendors come at scheduled intervals, potion ingredients always work the same way, the maps are static. No surprises. For someone looking for a very set game, this is good. I enjoy meticulously organizing my spell book, and it was satisfying to make sure I have potion paths I can deviate from to avoid some of the repetition and grind (I save a recipe just before making a potion, so that if I need a different variant later, I don't have to retrace my steps).

Cons:
That said, I hate the mouse precision. My wrist hurts from mixing and pounding herbs. The accuracy required to get a potion just right is a giant PITA. I frequently slip slightly and miss my level III potions, which is extremely annoying. I also struggle with the haggling for the same reason. Mouse precision is the biggest detractor of the game, hands down.

I also dislike how dim the map is. It's difficult to visually see where the potion locations are - they're marked, but not brightly. They should get large and stick out as you zoom out, instead of remaining proportionate to the rest of the map. I also can't fully zoom out of the water map, either. Definitely annoying.

I wish there was a little more in game guidance - gems were expensive so I hoarded them, never actually realizing that they teleport you. I didn't understand the whirlpools either, until I looked some things up. 

The addition of the oil map seems sort of meh. I wish all the potions were available on both maps. It's nice and all, to have easy access to some of the hard potions from the water map, but in general it seems a little meh.

The complex potions required for the end game alchemy crafting are just unnecessarily tedious. I keep a meticulous spell book, and the spells needed to create the philosopher's stone make a huge stack! Let alone the end game salt.

Neutral comments:
Neutral thing that some might like or dislike: the music is a short loop of medieval-sounding flutes / lutes. It's repetitive, which I'm fine with, but some might find it grating.

I am used to more pvp fast paced-games, but got burntout and wanted to look for solo games
I tried cultist simulator, xcom and some other (maybe I should check stardew valley?!). These seemed like stuff I would enjoy, thematically, mechanically, but I did not exactly work as intended, eventhough those are great games: there were some intrinsic hardship and pressure embeded that resembled the games I wanted to take a break of.

Potion Craft on the other hand fits like a glove to the lvl of casual play I was looking for. You have 0 time pressure, can explore many different ways to do things "mostly freely" while still offering challenges mechanically and on resource management. Following the Chapters is a good way to aim for the next steps, but I let myself wander throughout the map seeking for the new potions that I could come across (whilst gathering some extra xp hehe).

Some reviews say it can be repetitive. For me it felt quite the opposite, I was actually very inclined on doing many of the recipes by hand, looking for better procedures/sequences so that I could maybe find a nicer, more optimized path to a potion with the ingredients I had stockpiled.

Speaking of the recipe book, I am onto a more extreme customization approach on this matter: at the current state it works, but I would very much appreciate a higher lvl os customization regarding bookmarks, so that more than an icon can fit it, maybe change border color? add a custom shape around the icon? stuff that could differentiate two different recipes for the same potion.

I am on the fence about recommending this game. I think, at any time before the 10 hour mark, I might have rated this game much higher. However, the quest for 100% completion kind of soured me on the experience. Later objectives, such as the max reputation achievement, require mind-numbing levels of repetition, even when using the recipe book mechanic. Most of the late game recipes are less 'challenging' and more 'time sink'.

Even then, the nail in the coffin for me is that the game desperately needs accessibility options or alternate control schemes for those of us with weak wrists. The motions needed for every potion (grinding, stirring) can easily aggravate past repetitive strain injuries, to the point where there are user-made guides on how to write an AutoHotkey script to mitigate this. It's pretty unfriendly design from that perspective.

Fun and relaxing game, A game about an alchemist set out to build his own potion shop. The game concept itself is simple and addicting. Potion Creation system in this game used a map system, the potion as a ship of the map, the potion mark as the destination and a death zone serving in which will destroy the process. There is a reputation system where you can have different customer demanding for different potion. Its hard to run out of things to do. After 12 hours of playing I still have a lot to do and got introduced to more advanced mechanics of the game (in which I will not disclose).

Pros:
- Simple and easy to understand game with sufficient difficulty as level progressed
- Assets, Art style and UI of the game complements each other and forms a great environment.
- Customers and merchants stories to create world building of the game
- [b]THE PESTLE AND MORTAR!!![/b]
- A customized book to keep track of the recipe you have created.
- Great music
- Reputation and Popularity System to change types of customer and a haggling system.
- Potion Customization

Cons:
- Repetitive game play
- Requires a better Recipe book system once recipes pages have become cluttered
- Lack of interior customization
- Need a better sorting system for choosing ingredients (in the late quite confusing to keep track of everything)

Suggestions for future Updates:
- More Sound/ Voices Effects to better enrich the experience
- Needs an Encyclopedia of Potions already Brewed
- More Customization for every stations to better change the atmosphere.
- A garden system where u can specifically choose which plants to grow
- A notepad in game to that the player can write on to keep track of the player's current goal or needs.

Potion Craft is a fun and relaxing management game.

Pros: Funny customers asking for weird combinations of ingredients in their potions

Cons: You never get to see your potions in action. If you could get the smallest hint such as an image showing the outcome of your potion, the game would be much better. For example, lots of customers want Explosion potions and Wild Growth potions. If the game showed you an image of your customer using your potion to blast open a cave-in, or an image of your customer's crops growing to enormous sizes, that would increase the satisfaction you get from this game by several orders of magnitude.

Also, in my humble opinion, this game would greatly benefit from an Adventure Mode where you take on quests. For example, the King giving you a quest to chase away goblins. You could use an Explosion potion, of course, or you could use a Stone Skin potion to protect yourself during combat. You could even use a Charm potion to persuade the goblins to work for you instead. The possibilities are limitless in this sort of game.

If this game was a potion, I'd say that it has a very well-developed base, with many innovative properties ripe for expanding upon, has a pleasant smell and an appealing texture. But the rest of the potion was made by taking that wonderful base and pouring water. More, more, more water. More water. Endless deluge of the clear liquid, enough to fill the entire cauldron, flood the lab floor, and ruin your downstairs neighbour's ceiling. In the end, the aquatic ordeal leaves the potion completely devoid of anything it could've been, and you end up pouring it down the drain.

It starts out [b]fantastic[/b]. There isn't much of a plot, you're just a young alchemist who stumbled upon an abandoned workshop (biggest wish fulfillment of 2023) and decided to reopen it. People ask you for potions, so that's what you get them. The brewing system is ingenious: adding ingredients moves your "potion marker" on the effects map, and in order to get a particular effect, you have to reach its designated point, and heat the potion up to a boil.

At first, the map is pure joy to explore. You're constantly finding new effects, collecting experience books, finding out how the map itself works, and unlocking milestones that make you move forward in the "Path of the Alchemist", which unlocks new NPCs, new ingredients, new merchants.

But then... you slowly start noticing the unmistakable flavour of [i]repetition[/i]. Everybody wants a healing potion. Sure, I can brew you a healing potion. Oh, what's this? I'm out of a critical ingredient! But I can replace it with something else that "moves right", I'll just save both recipes so I won't have to do it again. Oh, but in order to get more exotic effects you have to move further into the map. And it's just so slow. So many ingredients just so you can explore the map. The same path, over and over again. Take the ingredient, smash it into pulp, put it in the cauldron, repeat. And again. And again.

Note that many actions are achieved by the "pumping power of the mouse" so to speak. So to crush an object in the mortar, you literally have to crush it by holding it with the mouse cursor. Same for stirring, same for pouring water, same for using the bellows. Not only this becomes extremely tedious later on, it also makes crafting tier 3 potions an exercise in ridiculous mouse precision (it's not about the recipe, it's about making the potion marker be [i]exactly[/i] in the right place. Hint: doing it is not fun).

Eventually, a new option shows up: you get an alchemy machine that's supposed to be able to craft legendary recipes. Wow, a gameplay change! Exciting! Until it turns out that those recipes still need lots of "normal" potions to be made, and often these potions require a weird combination of properties that will have you make your potion take a very long trip across the alchemy map...

And that's what this really boils down to. Everything is just so shallow and tedious. There is a reputation system, but it's pretty much a bare minimum. There is some dialogue with unique NPCs (including a discount Geraldo del Riviero), but it's quite rare, and incredibly short. There is a barter system with a nice dressing of difficulty levels and topics of conversation, but in practice it's just a QTE, and not a fun one.

Like I said: there's a solid base, but it ends up drowning in an industrial amount of water. There's more to complain about, such as the annoying way the game provides you with ingredients (they're working on this part at least), but I think I've said enough.

To wrap things up - some statistics. This is a game with 17k reviews at the time of writing, indicating a very successful, well-known indie game. And yet, the achievements paint a quite rapid dropoff rate. Some 50% of players have completed the first chapter, only 25% completed the third, 11% the fifth (I gave up right before that)... and only 0.9% have beaten chapter 10, the final one. Part of it is probably because a lot of people are drawn in by the unique art style without considering what kind of game it is, but I think a lot of people simply find the game gets very boring very fast. That's what happened to me at least, and I have an inkling I wasn't the only one.

Potion Craft: Alchemist Simulator is an awesome game that grabs my attention without even trying. It's the perfect choice when I don't know what to play or not in the mood for a specific game. Absolutely beautiful.

I remember getting this game before all the updates and achievements and such. It was already the most aesthetically pleasing game I've ever seen. It's genuine art, and what's better, it's the kind of art-style that doesn't age, kinda like pixel-art but medieval. The main gameplay loop was slightly short, but updates to the map and some of the other gameplay elements reworked that beautifully. Plus I got what I was most looking forward to: different bases for potions.

It's not a complex or difficult game by any stretch of the imagination and it's certainly not going to be a challenge, but that's not what I came for anyway. I came for the relaxing atmosphere and beautiful art, and that's  precisely what I got. The gameplay loop is loose enough to allow for mistakes while still retaining every single customer so there's not much need to worry. So far I haven't been in a situation in which I would need to optimize ingredients either. It's just a calm, satisfying experience. The exact kinda thing to wind down and relax.

The graphics look exactly as they're advertised, no corners being cut anywhere. Everything seems like it passes through a filter as a final pass over the graphics, because the paper lines align on different objects despite them moving around, joy to look at. Animations are clean and easily readable.
On top of that, the physics engine is a pure joy to work in, it's incredibly satisfying to throw items into the pot from a distance or bounce them off a wall or ceiling.
And last but not least, the UI is ever so intuitive and fun. It's hard to strike that balance between novelty and user-friendliness when designing UI, but this game managed it.

There's a couple very minor things I'd like to mention so that it doesn't look like I'm just an obsessed fan:
The music can get a little repetitive after a while, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, after all, it's supposed to be  a relaxing game and part of that is being predictable, but one could appreciate a few more tunes to choose from or unlock, something like enchanted forever-playing music boxes you could collect and switch between.
There's some minor hitbox/clickbox issues near the edge of the cauldron and the map, where clicking/dragging on the map will be ignored.
The cauldron also accepts ingredients into it even if they're only placed in front of it (not that you would do this a lot, I was just messing with the physics of the herbs).

Fun and chill. Music is very chill as well but if you get tired of it, it also plays very well with the Edgerunners soundtrack if you ask me. "CROSS-COUNTRY CARAVAN, NIGHT CITY ALIENS, I PULL THE TRIGGER AND I STILL FEEL NOTHING"
Oh, and I also find the colors/art of the game very soothing as well. Definitely enjoyed and recommend it!

I feel like this game needs more soul. For starters I'm pretty bummed out there is not even a hint of story. No way to give yourself a name, make your shop really your own. Even some cosmetic change up, unlocking some decor, giving your shop a name adding some more player directed dialogue from customers depending on your reputation would really help liven up this game. 

As many other reviews have stated the game becomes very boring after a while, especially as you end up making the same old potions again and again, make anything new or exciting and no one requests it. I think the game also needs a passive way to sell potions. Perhaps leaving them out on the shop counter means people can pick them up and leave cash, maybe its slightly lower than if you sold it directly (and you would not be able to haggle) but it would mean any experimental potions aren't wasting space clogging up the screen. I also find the small handful of customers per day irritating, I want more to sell too. 

In terms of game performance I have one issue I find very irritating. Sometimes, despite being more than centred to a potion icon on the map it refuses to upgrade to II or III which means I either have to stuff more necessary ingredients into my potion to re-centre it or get stuck with a weak potion. It's a pain I am tired of dealing with. 

Overall this game is fun at first but there is not enough to retain my attention. I really want more personality to it, I want to feel like the shop is my own, I want to feel like I am a part of this town, that my day to day means something in the game.

EDIT: After playing the game longer I have realised that a passive way to sell potions you make is what this game desperately needs. Requests are all good and dandy but having only them as a way to sell your potions, kills the incentive to experiment and play around creating potions as no one buys them (the poorly rotating requests is what makes game play so stale.) For this game to be truly a shop sim you need a way to sell of other potions for it to be engaging and enjoyable. 

In terms of resource management it would also be ideal if you could save maybe three variations of potion recipe since then it would account for the stressful resource management element, if the game recognises there are multiple ways to craft one potion it could save a lot of irate game play.

y'all remember flash games? the weird esoteric ones with unique mechanics fully explored in an interesting way? this is like one of those. in one of the coolest crafting mechanics i've ever seen, the game forces you to learn finesse and technique to preserve supplies of ingredients for personal projects while still serving customers' needs (cough, fuckin herbalist never stocks enough waterbloom, cough cough.) the ludonarrative of the crafting mechanic is really solid - each potion base represents the center of a space, different ingredients are aligned with different elements, and thus each ingredient moves the potion towards those elements' effects in different ways. grinding the elements in a mortar and pestle increases the distance they cover, and adding more base brings the potion back towards the center. "exploring" the space, by experimenting and pushing the boundaries, rewards you both with new effects and with experience. all of these things combine to make you genuinely feel like [strike] spiderman [/strike] you're very carefully preparing a potent brew. and that's not even getting into the alchemy system, which is also pretty in-depth.
admittedly it still feels a little "early access"-y in places, there are menus for tool upgrades (a mechanic which hasn't been implemented yet,) the garden doesn't feel fully implemented, there are only two potion bases, and the haggling system... kind of sucks, but there's still a full game here with lots to discover and a really good foundation. get it on sale or wait until the 2.0 release.

The game perfectly capture the feeling of starting off as a novice alchemist and gradually becoming better as the game goes on with the map system of potion-making; at the start it feels unknown and the only way to learn where every potion is located is through trial and error. As the game goes on, you become more and more familiar with the map and it feels more like a well-known path you travel through to get to your potions. The recipe book also adds to this feeling, starting off completely blank and as you go through the game it becomes dense and crammed with different recipes.

The way you create your path to the potions is also another great thing about the game! There aren't any bland ingredients that only take you in a straight, cardinal direction. They all have weird and complex designs that force you to become creative with how you tackle each obstacle.

Overall, if anyone wants to try out this game, I'd highly recommend it! The price is worth it!

This game is fun and interesting. I found it to be a very chill and relaxing experience.
And while I do have my criticisms of certain things, I still very much recommend this game.
But with that all being said, here were the "issues" I had with this game. 
It should be noted that the developer appears to still be tweaking and improving the game, so hopefully these issues will be improved for future players.

• By far my biggest complaint is that endgame is a slog. At day 90 I had popularity level 13, and had created every substance and had 2 or 3 optimized recipes for every potion. However to finish the questline, you need to reach popularity level 15. This took me another 54 days to complete, and it was 90% just quick brewing my saved recipes and throwing them at the customer. The gameplay is so reduced at this point, it's not even worth the effort to fulfill the more exotic requests (Give me hard potion X using only 1 type of ingredient). Just boot them out, take the -9 to your popularity, then fill out the next 19 easy requests at +4 popularity each. It took another 14 days to flip my reputation from +100 to -100 for the achievement, so by that math 40% of my days were spent grinding.

• You get more talent points than what you can spend on abilities. Either cap the player level, or give more abilities for us to buy. One of the talent trees (map visibility radius) is literally useless after a certain point. Talents to increase the popularity you gain for completing requests would help more to address endgame.

• The "Shop Upgrades" tab is useless. It makes you think that you'll get the chance to upgrade your equipment (Cauldron, Ladle, Bellows, etc). But the only thing "upgradable" is the Alchemy Machine (which is also fully unrealized, as it was clearly designed for more recipes than what is in the game, including a second chemical furnace that never gets used). If you mess up in the Alchemy Machine you make "Unknown Substance", which is useless outside getting the achievement. A recipe that gave it a use would be nice. I expected the ability to upgrade my "copper" equipment to increase potion efficiency (like making ingredients go further, or grind them together to change their effect path).

• Money is also useless in endgame. You can only really buy ingredients, but if you've optimized your recipes, you gain gold faster than you can spend it. I literally gave up haggling because I had 100k gold and 50~100 of each ingredient. If you could buy expensive reagents from the other alchemist (who SOLD you the machine, so he should be able to make them), that would be convenient.

• There's only 2 potion bases (water and oil), which is fine, but there's no need to list them in a sub-menu, as it makes you think there's more. You could just put them as 2 tabs at the corner of the alchemy map to make it easier to switch between them.

• It would be nice to have a better "statistics" page, that gave you an idea of how often you made and sold certain potion effects. I had an feeling that I only sold like 5 rage potions the entire game, while selling dozens of the others.

• I take issue with some of the descriptions customers use.
Asking for improved "agility" apparently means they want "Dexterity", not "Speed".
Asking for improved "reflexes" apparently means they want "Speed", not "Dexterity".

• The game never tells you this, but when making potions for the Alchemy Machine, the order of the effects do NOT matter.
As long as it has the same effect symbols, the machine will accept it. This is helpful to know as otherwise you might try to match the symbol order, which could involve moving to opposite ends of the map several times.

Overall though, I did enjoy this game enough to 100% it. It's charming and challenging, and the fact that the developer is still making improvements means that the game is only going to get better from here.

Run your own alchemy store complete with a magic tree that provides you with an endless supply of ingredients to use in your magical brews!

I had a lot of fun with this game at first. You get requests from customers, and have to brew a potion that meets their needs.
To make the potion, you have a map, and you use your ingredients to chart a path round the map to reach the desired effect.
Sometimes a customer will specify the ingredient they want in it, sometimes they’ll specify one they really don’t.

As you meet customers’ needs, you’ll gain more reputation, and customers will start asking for more complicated potions.

You do have a recipe book to automatically brew something you made before, so you don’t always have to do it from scratch. 

The game was really enjoyable for the first while, gaining new ingredients and finding new and more efficient ways to reach the effects you want. 

After a while it started to get a bit tedious as customers started needing new recipes with a maximum number of ingredient types and other such quirks that I couldn’t pull straight from my book. And brewing the philosophers stone and going round all the map getting the right effects was a little exhausting.

But overall, the game is enjoyable for the first 20 hours or so, so I’d definitely recommend it. It’s nice for just little chunks of gameplay here and there instead of a long sitting though. 

And it looks like the devs are working on new features like a garden system that might add some new variety into the otherwise repetitive gameplay loop. 

I originally played with family sharing but ended up buying it just to support the devs. I have no regrets.

[b]Potions brewed:[/b]   1500+
[b]Customers served:[/b]   1400+

---------------------------------
[H1]About the Main Objectives[/h1]
The main goals in game are to create legendary substances and their respective "consumables".
There are 5 Tiers of legendary substances and each need all the preceding tier ingredients to make, and you will need to make 2 substances of each tiers to complete the objectives.

i.e. You have just made a Tier 4 substance, and your next objectives will be making a Tier 4 consumable plus a Tier 5 substance.
So you will need to use your Tier 4 substance + 12 potions to make the Tier 4 consumable,
and another Tier 4 substance as an ingredient (making it from Tier 1 to Tier 4 again), + another 12 potions to make a Tier 5 substance. 
This situation happens in every tiers throughout the game, from Tier 1 to 5.

[H1]Why One-click Everyting[/H1]
You will be serving 1400+ customers, so you may not want to brew the potions from map every time.
And for the ingredient potions of legendary recipes, many of them requires you to travel back and forth the map, corners to corners, or 5 different spots on map.
So you will not want to do them twice for any recipes, but save the path of recipes so you can one click it when you need to make them again if needed.
The game becomes a resource management issue, you just need to replenish the ingredients, buying all the discounted goods from merchants everytime, and one click the recipes to serve customers until reaching the final reputation required.

[h1]Reputation System[/h1]
For the reputation system, there are no endings for the good or evil side, no stories or hidden missions to complete, just different types of customers you will encounter.

[h1]Consumables[/h1]
Consumable are so tedious to make, and you may not want to use them on fulfilling the customer additional needs, but just saving them to make legendary recipes. Therefore making the consumables are merely just objectives to complete the game.

"I'm not sure if the game is intended to be challenging or enjoyable when players have to spend a significant amount of time zigzagging around in search of a recipe for a customer. Perhaps there could be ways to streamline the process or provide clearer hints to make the gameplay more engaging."

Sounds about right.

This game needs a resource that you gain (via sleep or XP ?) and then spend to give you hints (e.g. cardinal directions) to where a certain recipe is on the map. Otherwise you're almost laughing at the player.

This game is so simple in its design and thus surprisingly addictive in the same way Game Dev Tycoon got me hooked. I have started over a few times because there is replay-ability. You can focus on being good or evil by choosing which customers to help and which to turn away and depending on who comes to you, the majority of the potions they want are different. Furthermore, you can craft various potions in an endless variety of ways and save the recipes. Customers will sometimes give you a challenge to make them a potion with only so many ingredients or using a certain type, which increases the strategy and puzzle-solving. I usually hate puzzle games, but this one is really fun because of how open-ended the solutions are. It is fun to find a way to make someone's request work; it feels like an accomplishment. I also like that you have to figure out what potion would meet the customer's needs. The balance and progression are just right. You can also design your potion bottles and the label art to be unique to each potion and/or each time you play, making your potions feel more like your own, personal creation. I recommend going onto Nexus and downloading some mods that improve the game even more, like the mods that help you organize your recipe book and the ones that add more ingredients. But even without mods, this game is incredibly fun!

How do you manage to ruin a game with such an obvious design flaw?
This game had (has? it's 2023 already) potential. While it is a simple idea, the map exploration using ingredients that give you different and non-optimal movements is actually pretty interesting. The actual sale part is not great but better executed than other games when you need to guess what customers wants from ridiculous vague descriptions.

So it holds up for the first few hours. And then, as reviews from YEARS ago complain about... you can't really progress much because of random and stingy offering of ingredients.
How can you go right when you don't have ingredients that go right? Or the ones that you do are extremely pricey and you can't afford using them in your potions..How absurd to design a game like this, I feel like my time has been wasted, I'm not going to grind for hours to get an ingredient that maybe allows me to get to the place I need to get to on the map.

All you needed to do was give the player a LOT of the basic four direction ingredients. That's it. The design could definitely be improved further with ways to grow the ingredients you want so you have a consistent supply, but if you just gave the player a lot of the basic ingredients you could at least attempt to explore more.

Despite its interesting early game I do not recommend buying this. You will only realize it's too grindy and flawed past the refund mark.

Fantastic game for those with anxiety. The simple progression, zero time pressure, and easy to understand game play has made Potion Craft my go to 'chill out' game for when I'm having a bad mental health day.

With the 1.0 release there's finally a lot of game for your money here. Potion Craft is surprisingly immersive for what it is; the graphics and sound are minimal, but what you're getting is a fantasy science kit that rewards curiosity and experimentation. After your first few potions you'll be eagerly cleaning out the Herbalist's inventory so you can brew more niche and outlandish concoctions. A few chapters in you start to acquire a sense that you're playing with fire and treading new scientific ground.

Sometimes it seems unfortunate that there isn't another layer here - that your experimentation isn't rewarded with emergent gameplay in some other parallel system, like being able to dungeon crawl with your own potions. But for the price I think Potion Craft does what it aims to do: provide a complex but low-stakes experimentation toy that's easy to grasp but also deep without being stressful or demanding to explore. It's been my go-to game when I want to unwind and watch something on my second monitor.

An interesting and enjoyable optimization/puzzle game, but it is a repetitive grind-fest--even before you try to 100% the game. That's not necessarily as bad as it sounds, but just be aware of it before purchasing. 

If you are devoting yourself to completing this whole game it will help to have your favorite show or music streaming in the background--it's going to be a long ride.

The RNG elements of the game can be downright cruel and even nonsensical at times. In the late game, customers will make ridiculous demands (some of which might actually be impossible). The money/reputation earned for complying only goes up very slightly while you stand to lose an entire 2 customer's worth of reputation/"honor." 

If you ignore these requests and the customer leaves, it's only mere seconds to earn back the points, but over the course of a full playthrough it will add up. One can only judge for themselves if spending the minutes trying to craft the perfect potion for a single customer--one that will likely only rarely ever come up again--is worth it over the long run compared to having to recapture the lost points.

The only thing you are really losing is your real-life time as the game remains on an upward trend line towards success as long as you keep serving most of the people.

The timer-based, quick-click, "haggling" mini-game will either break up the monotony or really mess up the relaxed nature of the rest of the puzzle-based game depending on your point of view. And, at least at the beginning of the game, it is something you can't afford to skip.

That all sounds a bit negative, but in reality the game is a lot fun if you take it for what it is. But you need to know what you are getting into before buying. That being said, if you want a game that will let you do some organization, optimizing, and problem solving in a unique art style, this will likely be a good choice.

РЕЦЕПТ ОЛАДУШЕК
Продукты:
Молоко - 200 мл
Яйцо - 1-2 шт. (в зависимости от размера)
Мука - 180-200 г
Разрыхлитель - 1 ч. ложка
Сахар - 2 ст. ложки (или по вкусу)
Соль - 1 щепотка
Масло растительное для жарки - 2-3 ст. ложки
1) Подготовить необходимые продукты.
2) Яйцо взбить с сахаром и солью в течение пары минут.
3) Добавить молоко, хорошо перемешать.
4) Муку смешать с разрыхлителем и добавить к жидкой массе.
5) Перемешать тесто до однородного состояния.
6) Тесто для оладий должно получиться гуще блинного.
7) На сковороду налить растительное масло, хорошо разогреть на среднем огне. На разогретую сковороду с маслом наливать тесто столовой ложкой и жарить оладьи до золотистого цвета с каждой стороны (ориентировочно по 3 минуты), при необходимости добавляя в сковороду масло. Если сковорода позволяет, жарьте оладьи по несколько штук за раз, у меня сковородка маленькая, поэтому я жарила по одной штучке.
8) Готовые оладьи на молоке подавать со сметаной или вареньем.

Potion Craft: Alchemist Simulator is a game that took me by surprise. I have always been drawn to games that allow me to create and explore, but I never expected a game about potion-making to elicit such a powerful emotional response.

As I began playing, I found myself completely engrossed in the intricate process of crafting potions. The game requires patience and attention to detail, but the payoff is incredibly satisfying. With each successful potion, I felt a sense of accomplishment that I hadn't experienced in other games.

But what truly struck me about Potion Craft was the sense of healing and catharsis that it provided. As someone who struggles with anxiety and depression, I often find myself searching for ways to calm my racing thoughts and find peace. And somehow, this game managed to do just that.

As I mixed ingredients and watched the colors swirl together, I felt a sense of calm wash over me. The repetitive motions and soothing music combined to create a truly meditative experience. And when I finally brewed a potion that cured an in-game character of their ailments, I felt a sense of joy and fulfillment that I hadn't experienced in a long time.

Playing Potion Craft felt like a form of therapy, a way to tap into my innermost emotions and work through them in a safe and comforting environment. I never expected a game about potion-making to have such a profound impact on me, but I am grateful for the experience. Potion Craft reminded me that sometimes the simplest things can have the greatest power to heal.

Anyways, it kills me to be giving a negative review of a well-made indie game. But the game has a few glaring issues that just prevented me from enjoying it:
1. The central gameplay loop is tedious. Oh my god it's so tedious. You wake up, brew potions, and give them to customers. It's fun for 2 hours until you realize the   e n t i r e   game is just... this. This is all you get. Forever.
2. The game is surprisingly punishing and it does not prepare you for this fact. Honestly, I would even say the tutorial and first few days are almost deceptive. To succeed, you need to conserve resources, experiment with movement patterns, and create alternate plant combinations for the same potion, but it's never really signalled to you that THIS is how you're supposed to play. You find out when you get kicked in the teeth and you're hemorrhaging money, customers, and reputation. I remember looking up what I was doing wrong only to find tons of other beginners asking the same thing.
3. There is a lack of any plot or any other kind of meaningful gameplay progression (disclaimer: I'm only 2 hours in, but I don't see any trace of one).

I cannot stress how much you just do the same thing forever. It's a shame because the game is well-made... I just wish a little more thought had been given to the central gameplay loop.

I would describe Potion Craft as a highly polished gem that was set into a piece of costume jewelry. The core gameplay is gorgeous, silky smooth, and extremely engaging, but it suffers from a lack of a cohesive story and a wider lack of depth in the long term. Towards the end of the game, I found more enjoyment from organizing my recipe book just so than from making potions.

Making potions is intuitive, entertaining, and easily mastered, and there is a very handy and very customizable (aforementioned) book for saving potions to auto-brew later, but brewing becomes a bit tedious in the middle and late game due to a relatively limited (not small, just limited) number of potion types and only two potion bases. Once you find all of the potion effects, then you've explored everything. There are also "legendary" recipes that give you special ingredients that unlock easier ways to traverse the base maps and create potions, but they are given to you automatically and act more as a progression limiter than anything else.

TL;DR: I highly recommend the game with the caveat that it suffers from a lack of depth in the late game. It is more than worth the money if you're looking for a relaxing sim.

The detailed review:
You make potions and sell them to adventurers, townfolks, good and evil people for different purposes.
The game contains several mechanics and inner games, complementing each other, which you need to progress in, in order to finish the game (potion discoveries, potion creations, selling to people which has haggle mechanics which I liked and is quite challenging at high levels, and alchemy machine creation and operation which gets very complex at high levels).
The way it works is you have a potion "discovery" map, the different potion locations are hidden from you, and the map is full of obstacles which you cant not see until you encounter them.
You navigate this map by brewing different plant and mineral ingredients into your cauldron, anywhere from 1 to infinite amount of ingredients, each one moves your location on the map based on a specific path unique to that ingredient, and you can take part of the path or all of it, and also use water the center yourself a bit in relation to your origin point.
Overall it allows for pinpoint exploration on a fairly large map that is not so easy to navigate with all the thorny obstacles.
You discover potion formulas on the map over time as you progress in discovering it and then you can make that specific potion you discovered and sell it.
There are maybe 30 potions or so, each unique, and you can create mixed effect potions, with 2 or more effects combined.
The customers come to your shop every day looking to buy potions to solve their problems. some are for good purposes and some are for evil ones, and you can decide to sell or not to sell, which affects your overall alignment as good or evil and which progressively affects the types pf future customers who show up at your shop.
At the same time there is a morale mechanics at work, which is part of your advancement in the game, based on how many potions you've discovered and sold, whether or not you've haggled for prices, your advancement with the alchemy machine and what you create with it, and this affects how many customers per day you get, which allows you to sell more potions and make more money.
You get the ingredients daily from your garden which grows them, which at first is all that you have, but as time passes, sellers start to appear and sell you ingredients, and you rely more and more on them, and you need to prioritize what to buy and try to haggle with them for better prices.
might sound a bit complicated, but its really quite easy when you get into it.

The game requires patience for potion discoveries, some strategy for potion creation and sale and some very quick reflexes for the advanced haggling mechanics,
I've played it for about 30 hours, and i'm not done, I estimate im about 60-70% away from full completion, and i paid 9.99 for the game on sale, so I got a about 50 hours worth of playtime for 10 euro (about the same in Dollars) which is a good and fair price.

Recommended.

[h1]A great core mechanic, but a bit of a slog[/h1]
I loved Potion Craft from the very beginning. The crafting system is so unique and engaging. Uncovering new effects and ingredients is very rewarding. It is mainly an open-ended problem solving game with countless ways to create any given potion. It is about understanding the core mechanics and to figure a way to create any given potion with as few steps as possible. Great!

However, even though I have reached the last chapter and only have a few more objectives left to finish the game, I have no interest to keep playing. There were certain points in the game where I felt I had to grind in order to progress; make more money, buy more ingredients and uncover more ingredients. There were no new mechanics for a while and no new problems to solve, just grinding. The game does pick up again a few times, but now there are those last few objectives which are only tedious instead of challenging. Making a crazy amount of potions I have already crafted or brewing new ones with effects that I already unlocked. The main issue is the recursive nature of the story required crafting where every higher tier ingredient requires the one from the previous tier compounding in just tedious repetition.

With all that said, I still highly recommend the game since the core mechanic is so good and it still gave me 15-20 hours of enjoyment even if I did not finish it. Your mileage may vary, but at its current price it is hard for me to not recommend it.
