*First impressions review*

I expected something akin to a cooking simulator game with a medieval twist, what I found was something straight out of Cthulhu's fish tank in terms of game mechanics and direction. I can't think of a game to compare it with. It's puzzle, exploration, efficiency, and resource management ground up in a mortar and pestle and tossed into a cauldron of chess-piece movement mechanics, fired up with risk reward. I've not even started with the unlocks and I hear this thing has a basement.

easy recommend, even without the haggle price.

This is a great game, it should be used as an example of how to make games in many areas: Gameplay mechanics design, art direction, execution...

The game is about making potions. Potions can have different effects based on the ingredients and exact recipe (obviously). There are many ways to obtain the same effect with different ingredients. Effects can be higher quality if you are particularly precise with the steps. You can save recipes you like so that you don't have to do steps manually every time, but the game limits the number of slots you have (you buy more slots as you make money).

Of course, there is a variety of ingredients and not all of them are good for every type of potion. You can get ingredients from different sources, but not all sources are equal. For instance mushroom man only sells mushrooms (not always the same ones), and you have to wait for him to show up. This means you have to tailor your recipes to available ingredients, and you have to maintain a selection of ingredients to cover different types of potions customer might ask for. I think this is a pretty fun aspect of the game. Ingredient scarcity gives you some pressure to think about efficiency, but also it's usually pretty easy to find ingredients if you really need it, so it's not a source of much stress.

The coolest thing by far is *how* the potions are brewed. It's not just a checklist of add this much of this, that much of that... There's a map, and every potion effect is a location on it. Every ingredient moves you in a certain predefined way. So it's about figuring out which sequence of ingredients will get you close enough, and also is something you can repeat multiple times with the ingredients you have. But there are various tools in the game that can modify the path of an ingredient, and there's a huge number of ingredients as well as multiple alternate maps, so you really get to explore a huge space of possible ways to make potions. The map is not revealed at the beginning, so there's an exploration aspect as well.

I think this map idea is brilliant. In real world chemical research there's a lot of efforts to summarize the essential properties of millions of possible chemical compounds, and then use that to automatically discover new reactions. One of the solutions to this, which I find really neat, is to calculate the similarity of all compounds (using the full list of their many chemical characteristics) and use machine learning and/or some fancy statistics to map this to 2D or 3D space so that similar things end up close together. Human brains are very good at comprehending physical space, but not good at comprehending tables of numbers, so this is a great way of leveraging that innate ability to make it easy for you to navigate a non-spatial thing (chemistry). This game is basically a gamified version of this approach. They've gotten the details right so it feels smooth, and it's very immersive to imagine yourself as a medieval alchemist who doesn't really know these modern statistical approaches, but is arriving at them intuitively through trial and error.

It's worth saying that the interface of this game, graphics, music etc. are really beautiful. They're all very polished and animations work smoothly. The controls are pretty good with a gamepad - the only issue is that you can't give a custom name to your recipes without a keyboard. The game is basically "find the recipe" (aka combinatorics, if you like math), but with the 2D map abstraction I described. You find the recipe over and over. This would suck if the UI wasn't slick, and in this game it's really slick. It doesn't really get old.

I found that it's a fun game to play with someone as well, taking turns every hour or so. You can play at a slower pace and have a conversation as you play, whether about the game or something unrelated. Most of your brainpower goes to planning and thinking, not fiddling with controls, so the person watching can meaningfully participate. A lot of winning tactics are circumstantial and subjective, so it's not a case of you figure out the solution and there's nothing more to discuss. You can always go back to old recipes or strategies and re-examine them.

Incidentally, pacing is another great aspect of this game. In most things you do, you can choose whether you want to do it with high stakes and more intensity, or lower stakes and more laid back. For example the haggling minigame is about reaction time. If you don't have fast reactions, or maybe you do but don't feel like making the effort that day, you can just choose the smaller haggle margin and get a slower minigame. If you're trying to make some amount of money, it takes you a bit longer, but it's not like the game becomes so slow that it's boring. Or you can go hard with higher stakes and advance faster. This isn't done by going to the game settings and fiddling with a "difficulty" slider - it's all part of the game to keep adjusting what intensity you want for each bit.

I'd recommend using a good gamepad for this. Something you do a lot is "grind" and "stir". Both are done by actually moving your cursor in a circle. I started with a cheap knock off Xbox controller (and also a knock off PS4 controller), and circling with the stick was not very pleasant (still playable). This was one of two games (other one was Sekiro) that convinced to fork over $60 for a real PS4 controller. It was a huge improvement because the coating and spring on the real PS4 analog stick is much higher quality and feels much more ergonomic. I never played with the mouse much - it seems playable, but I get shoulder pain from too much mousing so for me a gamepad is mandatory.

I feel like the game is pretty much perfect for what it is - a puzzle game with an original mechanic that is explored pretty in depth. Because the interface, graphics, audio, controls and other "minor" technical aspects are well done, the game feels very smooth and brewing potions for hours is relaxing rather than tedious. It's one of those games that you don't really care about completing, you just want to keep going back to the meditative experience. There is however a generous amount of progression when you want it - the game doesn't force you to progress if you feel like just staying at one level for a while.

I just wish they added voiceovers :)

When I was 17, I had a high school year-end project in my CS class which asked us to make a game. I spent 6 months designing and drawing up plans for my perfect potion crafting, alchemical game. I came up with some crazy RNG systems to make a potion game that truly felt like anything could happen. It goes without saying that that project was a complete and utter failure because I was over ambitious and had no idea what I'd gotten myself into. The point is, I was proud of the design, even though the game was a flop. And look, I was only 17, but I can tell you with absolute confidence that not in my wildest, most creative mushroom trip, not on the highest quality Intelligence Potion, would I ever, *EVER* have been capable of coming up with the sheer genius that is this game. The system is so remarkable, so unique, that it really beggars belief. The only way you can understand how clever this game is from an alchemical perspective, is to play it.

So go. Play it. It is an absolute steal at its full price. Buy it now, buy it under sale, I don't care, but at *least* give yourself a couple of hours to understand how deep this truly goes. At the very least, get a different Base for your potions, before giving up on it.

Cons:
- it can feel a bit grindy at times
- garden customization is still coming, so until then it can feel like you're missing some vital ingredients from time to time, but that's mostly on you

Beware of Potion Addiction.

Pro:
This game is all about optimization. The goal is to create potions efficiently so you can make a profit. The process is complex enough that you are always searching for a better way to make the potion. Think of it as a free-style puzzle game.
Con:
Some might get the impression from the store page that this game contains role-playing elements. At least in this early version, the game is not in any way an RPG. It is a puzzle and resource management game. The NPCs exist solely as ways to acquire gold or to trade for ingredients.
Summary:
If you like creative, problem-solving games, this is for you. If you are more into story-telling games, it is not.

I recommend Potion Craft. I'm also tired of it. Why recommend it, then? Because the first 90 percent of the game is good enough that I can overlook the last 10 percent -- for now. Potion Craft is a fun, chill game where you make and sell potions, become a pillar of the community, and use the proceeds to fund your secret alchemical research. It's good for relaxing while also making you think via problem-solving to get around ingredient shortages and find the most efficient recipes.

I have three main complaints. The music is the same short bit on loop for hours on end. Fortunately, a recent dev diary made it sound like more music is on the way. There's also a lot of RNG in what grows in the player's garden and what merchants sell. Some of this is understandable as it makes players be creative, but I went through long stretches when I was bereft of even the most basic ingredients and the garden's yields were paltry. Again, it sounds like this might be addressed in a future update.

My biggest complaint is the late-game grind. There's way too much for too little reward. There are 10 chapters, and you have to reach Level 12 popularity (500 stars) to finish Chapter 9 and Level 15 (1,250 stars) to finish Chapter 10. I completed everything but the popularity requirement for Chapter 10 by Day 59 in game, hit Level 13 popularity (750 stars) on Day 77, Level 14 (1,000) on Day 102, and Level 15 on Day 143. Hours of grinding for no real purpose when I was already awash in cash and ingredients, all to tick one final box. I had to talk myself into coming back to finish Chapter 10. My hope is that the devs put the popularity requirements in as a placeholder and will scale them back when there's more late-game content to add. If not, I fear many players will come to the conclusion the juice is no longer worth the squeeze once they hit the late game.

I loved the aesthetic and charming premise at first. It reminded me slightly of the atelier games, and thought maybe it would be a similar crafting system with item traits and rarity playing a part in the potions themselves. 

Pros:
1. Pretty medieval art
2. Soothing music (although there's only 1 theme so I kind of tuned it out after a while) 
3. Potion customization (the bottle shapes and symbols are very cute) 
4. No time limit, so not stressful 
5. You can be as shady as you want and help people melt/explode stolen treasure chests (although with what they pay you, you're getting conned).

Cons:
1. No storyline-- this is what made me stop playing since there's no true end goal in sight. Just a lot of achievements in a book. Which may be a pro for some, but I found myself thinking why I continued playing after the first 5 hours. 

2. Not much instruction-- for some reason, I thought the ingredient description/rarity was what had an effect on the potion level (not the end position of your potion cursor). I only found out after watching some LPs on it. So I wasted a lot of rare stuff early game because I thought rarer ingredients made better potions lol! 

3. Repetitive - Discover new potion, make, sell, spend all the money earned on expensive plant and mushrooms. Waste resources trying to explore the map, miss the perfect position by half a mouse-click, accidentally graze some bones and burn your potion entirely, silently swear and restart. I'm only 7 hours or so into it, but that was a big chunk of my experience XD

Overall: Enjoyed it at first, but instead of being excited to progress the achievements I just found them tedious and stopped. I think it's good as is just for a casual few hours of enjoyment, but it would be more fun if there were more variation of other things-- like more gathering, gardening, visiting other shops/places, maybe some kind of quest line to keep being invested.

It's an alright game, but a bit simplistic. The artstyle is nice but not really worth writing home about, and there's not really much in the way of characterization I've seen thus far. The only actual characters are merchants who don't even have names, and while nice, there's not much to say on them. As for the customers, there's no real conversation there, just a description of what they want.

The haggling system is pretty simple as well, nothing bad about that but it's just not really got anything to it.

The big sell on it is the potion crafting system, which requires you to use different ingredients to traverse a sort of chemical map to find the effects you want. This is actually a pretty fun system, but it's a bit hindered by a lack of explanation. The potency of effects is determined by how you can align your bottle symbol on the map with the effect symbol's bottle. Issue is, there is no explanation I've seen in game thus far for the bottles that are rotated and that prevents you from getting the best of an effect.

Overall, while the Potion system is not perfect, it's the main focus and, of course, saving grace of the game, but it seems like it would be a better fit as an element of a larger game. That said, overall, it's still a decent time filler sort of indie game.

i was going to be charitable and just not review this game, then i remembered i payed $15 for it.

this is very fun in the early game -- its a unique crafting mechanic, and a well thought out one. it *is* good for what it is. but if you keep playing, the novelty will wear off at some point. and then you're left with... what?

the goals are repetitive, theres no story (the "chapters" are just collections of tasks to do for the achievement, and once youve unlocked everything theres no purpose to doing it.). the balancing leaves something to be desired; once youre at the higher popularity levels, refusing a single customer -- even if their request is *impossible*, which they sometimes are -- will lose you double what youd get from helping them. past halfway, the game is just grinding. but its grinding that doesnt *lead* anywhere.

there are a few features that seem outright missing. the only way to discard potions, for example, is to melt them down in your alchemy machine to make a new undestroyable item. reportedly theyll be adding in garden upgrades -- which is great, but i feel like that shouldve been in the initial release. the garden right now is essentially useless once you can afford merchants.

overall, this feels like... more of a game *mechanic* than a full game. and its a great mechanic, sure -- but it needs more.

Far too much of a grind. Much of the game's mechanics just aren't synergistic. I've had enough gold in my playthrough since the end of the first month to clear out the inventory of every merchant that comes by -- even the marked-up items -- and yet, despite also having some pretty optimal recipes for each strong-quality effect, using the most efficient ingredients and using an oil base when necessary, I am often bottlenecked by the scarcity of ingredients, so I can't progress the chapter and have to just wait and hope I get lucky enough for the right merchant to drop by next run. I can see how that variability of ingredients could be fun and push you to approach potions creatively, but serving the same requests a dozen times before you can log off the game is such a drag, you just get pissed off when a patron gives you some oddball request, even with substantial gold yield; and when they don't give you that much gold, it feels like the game is insulting you. This game makes me audibly groan, but I've sunk so much time into it, I feel like I have to see it through. 

And I'm doubly insulted when I sail around the whole water map over and over again to make an ingredient in the alchemical machine, only to see that the "save recipe" button isn't an option. And I ask to myself, "Should I make more than one of this ingredient? No, they would give me that option if I need more than one for the playthrough, right? And I only have so much of each ingredient," only to unlock the next recipe and see that I need to make that previous ingredient again, right after I deleted the recipes for the previous one to make space.

The gameplay loop is fun but far too shallow for how much it overstays its welcome. This game does not respect your time.

Seven hours later into the game. I figured out I can make multiple recipes for a single effect. I've decided to brute force the special ingredients by buying a whole bunch of magic paper, more than can even fit on the recipe book screen. I just made five albedo and all the necessary recipes for the philosopher's stone...and the game just crashed on me. Just rebooted the game, and all my recipes are gone. Hours of work, down the drain, because I didn't want to go to bed and have to deal with more customers before being allowed to save. I think I'm going to commit Minecraft.

Let's start with suggestions first:
- I'd love to be able to share my recipes with my friends!
- When hovering over an ingredient, it tells you how many recipes use that ingredient (Maybe if you click on the number, it shows you which recipes exactly).

Feedback:
*This is going to include some end game content so please be aware of SPOILERS.
The only part of the game that I did not enjoy was the salt recipes! To me personally, the end result was not worth the effort and time! Here are some details:

- The Void Salt: Being able to remove my path is cool and all but honestly, I have never used this salt and if I did I never saved the recipe! As you get better at the game, you don't really need it!

- The Moon and Sun Salts: I think having a salt that rotates potions if a very neat feature but having 2 types is not really efficient! Why would I spend so much time and resources to make the sun salt when I can make a lot of the moon salt easily. I've never used the sun salt! Never needed it because the moon salt is MUCH cheaper and easier to make!  

- The Life Salt: Honestly, to me personally, half the fun of the game is the risk of dying to bones! If I have this salt then I am basically invincible! And that's unfortunately kind of boring!  

- The Philosophers Salt: This is my biggest complain and the one that actually disappointed me the most! This salt is so tedious to make and the effect you get from it is really not worth it! Why would I use a very expensive salt to correct my mistake when I can just add one or two cheap materials that I have 200 of to do the same thing?

I wrote down a couple ideas that I personally thought would be cool to have instead of these effects: For instance:
- A Salt that lets you remove a potion effect so if you make a mistake while brewing a potion with multiple effects, you have a second chance instead of starting all over again!
- A Salt that either increase or decreases the intensity of the potion! Or one that can "unbrew" a potion so I can change the intensity of it! A lot of the times, if a customer was asking for a weak potion that is hard to get to like Luck, inspiration or perfume and I already saved the strongest recipe, I'd just turn them down and get to the other ones because it probably won't be worth the time and effort.

Overall, I do really enjoy Potion Craft and I think it's very unique and has a lot of potential!

Thank you for bringing us joy! :D

Cheers,

Every time I try to play an alchemist in an RPG like Skyrim, I'm left feeling a bit disappointed. So when I saw this game on steam, I expected it to be an amusing diversion that would hold my interest for a couple of hours and nothing more. I opened the game and started brewing at 11:00 am on a Saturday. Nothing to do today, so might as well kill a bit of time.

I especially enjoyed coming up with names for my concoctions. A man came into my store asking for some sort of poison that he could use on some rich people who liked to visit a sauna. After a bit of experimentation, I managed to make a strong potion of poisoning. Since this was a group of people, I naturally chose a bottle that looked like an old timey perfume bottle with the little rubber bulb for spraying. I named this concoction "Axe Body Spray" and gave the following description:

Uses: Permanent incapacitation on a room-wide basis
Directions: Stand in the center of a crowd and spray on your person. For best results, apply liberally in a poorly ventilated location such as a locker room or on a bus.

Thoroughly pleased and chuckling to myself, I passed a few more in-game days, filling my recipe book with similarly humorous entries. After a few hours of this I decided it was time for a break. Huh. That's weird. It's still 11:00. Why is it dark outside? WHY AM I SO HUNGRY?

10/10 will brew again (but with a timer on my phone)

Potion Craft is the definition of: Wide as a puddle, Deep as an Ocean

I wish I could tell you that this game has an interesting story- it doesn't
I wish I could tell you the NPCs had engaging dialogue, or that your decisions to create certain potions for them, or deny shady customers actually matters - None of that exists

But, what Potion Craft has is one of the most engaging puzzlers I've seen to date. A SANDBOX puzzle game where the player is allowed to dictate how much automation goes into their shop through the form of recipes. Creating better potions, better recipes, and ultimately filling what one would consider to be the "Perfect Potion Recipe Book" quickly become your end-goals as you carve your knowledge into this world as an Esteemed Alchemist.

Over time you eventually prove yourself by creating 'complex' potions that are used in the creation of "Substances." These substances are then repurposed into Dusts, which can then be added as ingredients to your potions- effectively unlocking a much deeper and complex game than the player is originally introduced to. Through the form of these dusts, new ingredients, and new goals to create new Substances the player is quickly wrapped up in what you could call "The Pursuit of Knowledge"

I felt incredibly refreshed delving deeper and deeper into the puzzle mechanics that comprise Potion Craft, and I can't wait to finish my last few Recipes up and finish creating 'The Philosopher's Stone'

A game that is easy to learn but hard to master. Perfect for those perfectionists who desire only the best, most efficient recipes of potion crafting. Many different ingredients and paths to create potions of all types, by using different methods. Large potion map that has challenging, tight portions that can be difficult to guide the concoction through, but can be avoided by using the game's well made crystal mechanic that can bypass certain sections of dangerous deadzones. Engaging merchant system which the player can barter for better prices at a risk, and small requests from said merchants to unlock a larger variety and amount of ingredients for future potion making.

Pros: This game includes a crafting system I really enjoy and does involve a bit of skill - the jolt of satisfaction you get when you create a perfect potion is ~chef's kiss~. 

Cons: I'm not particularly motivated by the chance to create the philosopher's stone and completing the chapters (these help you progress, permitting you to get new/interesting requests and ingredients). I just like to make potions all day long and sell them. :-( 

I also wish there were more recurring/interesting/plot-driven customers, sort of like "Papers Please". After a while, the characters are a bit repetitive.

Otherwise, a great chill and zen game to pass the time. Gotta make more potions and feel very medieval

I'm enjoying this game a lot! It's very chill and there's something I find very satisfying about the process of running my little potion shop. I will say that progression in this game is limited by the random arrival of certain merchants to your shop, from whom you need to buy key items, and if you don't have the funds together when they first arrive, you simply have to run the shop day-to-day until they return. This means you really have to take it at a relaxed pace - this maybe isn't one for the kind of player who likes to rush progression and complete everything as quickly as possible.
Progression also requires you to make increasingly complex potions, and this requires exploration of the potion-making maps, but if you use all your resources to explore you won't be able to fulfil customer requests, so you must balance your personal research with the running of the shop.
If this sounds slow and boring, perhaps the game isn't for you, but if you enjoy a slower pace, filling out your recipe book with the most efficient paths to different potions, perhaps even customising your potion bottles and labels to make things look more interesting, then this may be the game for you.

More potion types!
More potion bases for added later-game challenges!
Monster parts as alchemical reagents!
GARDENING!!
New plant-based and crystal ingredients with new effects!
New NPCs!
New Quests! 

and so, so, SO much more. They're really committed to their game and it shows!

In short, this game is fun and I spent my morning playing it, but it really needs more content. I expected way more control over what happens in your shop because I mean, the description literally says, "You're in full control of the whole shop." Which is a lie.

Let me tell you why:

You have zero control over which herbs you collect because you aren't growing your own, you are simply harvesting whatever you find in your garden and buy from whatever vendor happens to stop by. You can't mix and match different herbs to create your own which the description also states. You can only create what the game allows you to, which isn't experimenting at all. 

You can choose from different potion abilities to create your own. Example: "poison/acid." However, that isn't really experimenting, it's more just combining a few things that your customers aren't even asking for. 

The lack of experimental potions is disappointing because that's one of the reasons I bought the game. 

To wrap up the review, I feel like the game was only fun because it's basically alchemist themed "Dealer's Life" which I played before on my phone. 

So, is it fun? Yeah, you'll get a few hours of game play but it gets annoying and you'll soon realize there's a lot about the game that needs revamped. 

Is it worth the price? No. I got it on a sale and paid $11 for it, and I still feel a bit gypped.

I wish there was a "meh" recommendation, but I'm giving it a thumbs up just because I was able to burn 3 hours playing.

I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. I had quite a lot of hope for a new cozy game from this title, so i picked it up on sale.

The artwork and premise of this game are great, really charming and I really wanted to enjoy playing it. However, i just didn't. I found the gameplay really repetitive and not very engaging, the tutorial sections missed out some key points about potion brewing and I quickly found myself having to google aspects of customer requests as a couple of them just don't make sense to me (or should really have multiple solutions) as well as having to google the "map" because it was way too easy to just waste all your ingredients just to end up in the completely wrong place, meaning you then couldn't fulfil orders and thus not make money to buy more ingredients...

it'd be nice if you could actually spend time gathering ingredients rather then a 5 second click this screen to get 10 random herbs process, it made it near impossible to consistently fulfil orders due to being short of a couple of key items that it's pure RNG if you get (and there aren't too many substitute items either)

I suppose I expected more of reading what a herb is an it's traits, using that with complimentary herbs rather than the description really meaning very little other then (it goes X direction) and once again because of the scarcity of some herbs you'd have to use different recipes each time which requires a lot of manual time wasting in the brewing process. Which on that note is not very accessible, I have no issues with mobility or my wrists but after having to manually brew 2-3 larger potions in a row I had developed an ache, I figure this could be circumvented in the settings but there is no such option (even a click and hold to auto-do the animation would improve this!)

overall this game has a ton of potential to be a really cute, relaxing cozy game but right now I just find it monotonous in the worst way and sadly boring. I think improving the brewing process (such as letting us see the full map so at least we can try and guess our way around rather than being blind) adding depth to the recurring characters (they give you tiny personal tidbits but it's barely present) and making some kind of more interactive way of gathering herbs would make this into a fantastic little game, as it already has so much going for it.

Right now I honestly wouldn't recommend it as it feels like an early access game, though i would love to see where it goes in the future if the developers choose to keep adding to this title

This game is simple in concept, and CLEVER in how it plays out. The crafting system is seamless, and fun. Presenting the development of recipes as a path along a map that reveals itself as you progress is genius. It even has an ALIGNMENT feature. Definitely worth playing!

I'll say it right here: This is the exact template that all CRAFTING systems in MMORPGs should be. Instead of grinding out useless items forever, this game shows that you can build a crafting system via NPCs that buy your stuff, until your skill level is high enough to reach the attention of PCs. It's really well developed, and worth the price to play!

This game design should also be put into place for almost any class in MMO:
wizard...a map that leads you to new/more powerful spells
fighter: a map that leads you to new movement combos/attacks
etc.
Instead of "you leveled up so now you get x ability, you should level up by *FINDING* the ability via a system like this game.

I'm going to recommend this game because there is plenty to like about it: the art style is beautiful, its challenging to explore the map to find new potion effects, and you really do feel that the process of grinding the herbs and mixing the potions involves you in a physical way that means you are not just a 'god' type influence on what is happening as you serve your customers. 

But, there is still something that is missing here for me. I've started the game three times now, and each time, I have become a little bored with the constant grinding and mixing, serving customers and picking or buying new plant stock. You have to do a lot of that in order to progress through the 'chapters' ie. a set of tasks you have to complete to move on to the next stage, some of which are difficult to manage because you run out of herbs really quickly, and buying them in is far too expensive, therefore, your profits become slimmer and slimmer, particularly when you have to give potions away to the 'collectors' so they can level up the stock they can offer you...and then, to afford replacing the very pricey Alchemy machine and its various parts. Yes, it all has a point: so you can level up your knowledge, and the range of potions you can offer, but I feel, at the expense of just 'grinding' through the process until you get bored with doing the same things over and over again. 
There is no story line, or ability to be able to control (very much) how many herbs you'll have in stock at any time...I keep having to 'go to bed' so I can get more herbs from the garden...I feel like I am fighting a losing battle for no end game achievement. Will the King ever have need of my services to produce six strength/stone skin potions that will help his knights defeat a dragon or am I just sitting here and serving a bunch of nitwits who need my potions for silly things, like blowing their front doors open because they've lost their house keys? It hardly feels epic, and I'm thinking that's the hole in the entire thing. 

While I do realise the game is 'unfinished' and that the Devs are planning more content for the coming year (including being able to grow your own plants - this will help a great deal, and I am looking forward to that), it needs a lot more work on the end game achievement factor and some challenge quests, or it just becomes a grindy snooze, fairly quickly. 

Hoping to see more reason to carry on before falling asleep, for real. :}

If I could change one thing, it would be to add some complexity to the ingredient harvesting (maybe change it to a rudimentary gardening system?), but that's a rather small critique all things considered.

The game is amazing and has extremely well-designed and thought-out systems. Amazingly fun, charming and beautiful all over.  There are a few games on steam that are, without a doubt, the best of their kind and will never be surpassed like Stardew Valley for Farmsims, Terraria for Crafty-Shooty-2D-Sandbox games or Hitman 3 for stealth sandboxes. Potion Craft is definitely the best alchemy simulation and, without a doubt, no game will ever be better at it.

There are tons of reviews rightfully praising this game, so let me focus on what I didn't like:

I recommend this game up until about chapter 8, which is when the game becomes grindy busywork. A shame really, the endgame is just annoying and repetitive, because you'll have met every customer by then and they keep coming to you with the same petty problems over and over. I get that its hard fill the game with 100s and 100s of customers, but it would really profit from more different and varied mix-potions that people require and incentive to deliver exactly what they need, rather than just giving them a half-assed potion and hoping for a better customer next in line who needs what you have already pre-made or what you have a recipe on hand for. There really is no reason to spend 10 minutes making the exact potion that this guy needs if I can just give him the ol' HP-pot or even just kick him out. Also making the stones and salts doesn't really feel worth it, but rather cumbersome and annoying.

But up until chapter 8 I highly recommend this game! It is very unique and you will never find a better alchemist simulator on Steam. Well worth the money!

Very well crafted game, that translates the potion brewing mechanic into an exploration/puzzle game. The graphics look really nice and charming, and it has a lot of content.

Main issues of the game:

* The lack of garden customization in the late game, which leads to rng.
* Salts simply should't be limited for the effort they take, or they should be easier to make again (less ingredients, like requiring no crystals the second time).
* There should be more space for recipes in the book (it will become cluttered). Empty pages could be removed from the book and instead replaced with a button that allows the player to add a new page.
* The popularity requirements become ridiculous later and seem to be mainly for artificially lenghtening the game.
*  Selling should become more automated with time, especially regarding the easy potions. For example, adding a shelf where customers can automatically pick up and pay for their requested potion, should it match.

Overall, regardless of the criticism, it still is a fun and unique experience for some hours.
Potion Craft is a decent game, but I recommend waiting at least six months to purchase it.  There should be many new features implemented by then.

A few suggestions from my opinion: 

* Instead of waiting for merchants to come to you, they should be available all the time (with more expensive/less wares as to not remove the challenge) 

* People need more reasons, preferably with varying words and personalities if possible, to purchase potions so they seem more human-like rather than not.  

* A quest system would be nice. I know there is the "Alchemists path" but what I'm thinking is one that goes through customers for larger requests. Like 10 potions of healing. Then you could get time to make whatever is requested which increases/decreases depending on difficulty and materials cost of what was requested.

* Larger requests. This would not use the quest system (if it were to be implemented), but rather just be a few potions to get right away. This could require balancing, but it becomes a little bleak to know that one potion is all that's needed to do whatever they need to get done.

Overall the game is nice. Would like some different songs as it gets kind of repetitive to listen to the same track again and again even though it fits very well.

The game doesn't feel like it's actually finished. I was initially wondering why the version numbering jumped from 0.5.0 (the final Early Access version, I believe) straight to 1.0.0 after a couple months - I realize that version numbering is often not consistent, nor is it standardized, but the gap did seem strange. After playing for a few hours, I really do think it "left Early Access" without actually leaving Early Access. And there are parts of the system that I find to be pretty annoying. A lot of parts, actually.

- progression is based on completing lists of objectives; each list is a "chapter". this is fine. what's not fine is that those objectives seem to always include "spend a ton of gold on stuff from the alchemy vendor", who seems to only appear at the start of random days. i felt like there were a lot of days that i was just filling orders for the sake of filling orders, waiting for the vendor to reappear.
- the game takes a lot of time to play. saving recipes will save you a lot of that time. but what if a customer asks for a potion whose recipe you don't have the ingredients for? making the potion manually might get you like 200 gold, but it's going to take a few minutes and you could just refuse them. it sucks losing a few rep, but the 600+ gold i'm about to get from someone who wants a poison potion definitely helps assuage that pain. 
- the fancy recipes in the basement are cool, until you realize just how many times you'll have to make them, even just to progress in the later chapters. hopefully you have enough magical paper to save the recipes for their ingredient potions, because the fancy recipes have a "save recipe" button that's not clickable. (coincidentally, this is one of the devs' "features we'd like to add someday")
- "exploring" to find new recipes is cool, i actually really like it. i don't like that accidentally moving too close to the bone areas will delete your attempt, alongside all the ingredients you already put in the cauldron. some of those might have been the last few you had, so good luck getting back there again.
- don't have the ingredients you need to make half your saved recipes? haha have fun not getting any in the free 20 herbs in your garden, then the vendor not even appearing that day, and then appearing the next day but not even selling that ingredient. time to go remake all those recipes without it. (i had multiple recipes that used spellbloom, and then a solid 5+ days where i did not have spellbloom and didn't have the option to buy it. that was fun)
- the garden is... not worthless, i guess, but bad. free ingredients are nice, but you have no control over what you get, no way to get more per day, no way to regrow within a day... nothing. (yeah that's also in the "features we'd like to add someday" list, lol)
- boy howdy i love exacerbating my RSI by wiggling the mortar and pestle, or wiggling the cauldron spoon, or wiggling the bellows. 3-4hrs of playing this game made my wrist hurt worse than Path of Exile ever has, and i have some 2-3k hours in that. which imo kind of says a lot.
- there's absolutely no indication i saw (i could be blind) that whirlpools aren't dangerous and can teleport you. usually they teleport you backwards for some reason, and occasionally warp you into the middle of a bunch of bones. so actually maybe they are dangerous. at least their destinations are static.
- gems can teleport you on the alchemy map. i'm pretty sure the game doesn't tell you this. they're rare and expensive, so i never thought to use them, until a gem was the only way i had to move in a certain direction. i spent quite a lot of time carefully navigating through bones before then.
- there's a menu that shows all your alchemy tools, like your spoon, your cauldron, your mortar, etc. the way it's laid out makes it look like there might be tools you don't have yet, and there might be upgrades to those tools. iirc it even says you can buy better tools from vendors. yeah, no, the menu is useless, vendors don't sell better tools that i saw. (oh hey, another item on the "features we'd like to add someday" list, kinda weird)

This game is a 8,5/10 if you ask me, I take this review very seriosly and with that, Im going to show all good and bad things: 
Good: 
The Graphic: The graphic is most likely the first thing a potential customer notices, its pretty unique and reminds you of the medieval times. The artstyle is well made and consistant, the plants and potions look great and the background has a nice claming colour and have a more "old" kind of style. Just overall very pleasing for the eyes.

The brewing: Big surprise, in a brewing game, the brewing system is pretty good. But for real, its somewhat addicting but not the craziest thing you can imagine, here come things the devs can change... the brewing system in this game is by far the best one ive ever seen but It feels pretty much the same all the time, making at some point brewing just really... boring. Especially if you have enough ingredients. But as said, its still really fun. 

The music: It reminds me of skyrim or maybe something like WoW, where the music just puts you into the game. Like the brewing system, its not something ground breaking or crazy but it does its job pretty well and deserves to be mentioned.

The bad:
The trading system: Welp, time to attack the game for its lower parts. Starting of with the one, that makes me the most salty: The trading system. When you see how much the devs developed the brewing system, you would think that they would also put at least half the effort in the actual selling part of your potions... but nah. The trading system is boring as hell, to the point where I have more fun reading the despriction of the themes of the trading, than the actual trading. This is so dumb and it would be the best to actually make the trading somewhat more interesting or engaging. 

The leveling: Its not really balanced... or engaging. The skill tree is like the trading system more boring than anything else, but in the case of the skill tree, it feels like a made up one from fourth graders. I really do not care for the progress thanks to that in terms of the actual level. Another thing are the potions the people want from you, its nice to see them being pretty special or unqiue, but getting a bunch of bad ponts in reputation and popularity just because that idiot wants a posion you cant craft or havent even found yet, just feels like a punch in the face. I see why the devs did that, which is why I consider this exact problem to be more personal than objectiv. 
(Quick sidenote, after creating this comment, I looked up the roadmap for the game and found out, that they want to update the skill tree, so Im curios if I can change this comment later on :))

This is a great game, and a very creative concept. The in game economics is manageable but not so easy as to not exist. The creation of potions is fun and requires creative thought, but is also pleasing to do. The ingredients and map layout play nicely into the alchemical and elemental themes. The Long arching goals behind the alchemy machine give an interesting set of puzzles to solve, and the customer related quests are interesting if repeated often, but have different solutions that customers will pay different prices for. All in all, pretty fun and captured my interest for a non-stop 12 hours of game play. Literally one sitting.

Edit after completing the game's content:

This is a good game. But possibly the best part about it is the promise it holds for creative and complex content to be added in updates. The current game is a solid base, all the mechanics and systems are functional and enjoyable. Importantly the potion shop-customer interaction system is well designed. It doesn't contain the full range of reactions from customers regarding unique potions that might fix their specific problem in a more creative way. But that is some thing the developers promise in future updates, and would give the game an even greater depth. The garden management would also be great. I really  enjoyed the 25 hours I've put in, but this game is essentially a puzzle game and now that I have saved some really perfected recipes for every customer need, as well as creating the philosopher's stone, and finishing the alchemists path. I've completed all the available puzzles. I eagerly await the developer's adding more nuance customer needs, as that is essentially adding more puzzles to solve.

Edit after full release and 30+ additional hours:

Great game. Continues to get better as more content is added. The full released version contains substantially more puzzles, and more ingredients and uses for the salts made with the alchemy machine. The game is great, and yet even more is promised from the developers in the form of garden management and nuanced customer needs. In the recent release they added some detail to customer requests, but they still don't have extra rewards for potions more specific, for example if a customer asks for a "potion to make them better in battle" they pay the same for 3 strength potion as they do for a 3 strength 1 dex 1 swiftness potion. While saying in either case "this potion is perfect" when clearly the 3 strength potion is good, but not perfect, as the addition of dex and swiftness obviously would help in battle. The update they actually made is that sometimes the customers will demand the inclusion of specific ingredients or ask for multiple effects. Fine, but not the pinnacle of whats possible for this game. 

All in all, very great game. Worth buying.

I wish I could recommend this game. The core potion-brewing mechanic is quite well done and and UI is charming and uniquely tactile. Unfortunately I have two major issues with the game.

The first and simpler issue is that the game really just isn't finished. The UI has placeholders for upgrades to your tools that don't exist, the prices of some potions are based on a potion base that isn't in the game yet, and one mechant talks about mechanics for the enchanted garden that it doesn't have. While these things are on the development roadmap, these blatant gaps aren't acceptable for a game that's left Early Access.

The second problem, and one that I'm not sure will be solved with time, is that the game just doesn't have enough going on to keep the player engaged for its duration. While the potion-making mechanic is pretty fleshed out, it's not SO deep that it can carry the entire game, and there's very little to running the shop outside of that. Besides potion-making the only other concerns are reacting to the random availability and prices of ingredients, and haggling (which is just a timing minigame). Though even if the economic side of the game had more depth, the game expects you to spend a LOT of time brewing unique potions to make legendary recipes, too much time for the amount of depth the mechanic has.

Once the devs have implemented the missing features, I would be able to recommend the game on the condition that the player is content to enjoy a fun, unique smaller game for a few hours. Those who are expecting a lot of depth or those who would be bothered by not being able to reach the end without a lot of grinding should look elsewhere.

I like the game, but I have some huge caveats and suggestions to the devs.

First and foremost, the concept of the game is highly appealing to me and I love how 'tactile' it feels. Grinding ingredients feels different depending on its type, and I really enjoy having to physically interact with my equipment. It is definitely the highlight of the experience. Exploring for additional potion unlocks can also be a rewarding challenge.

On to my suggestions.

The garden needs a serious revamp. I see that you have something like it planned for a future update. Without knowing the specifics I'm not sure if this is a situation you have already addressed in this future update. Regardless, I recommend prioritizing this garden update and releasing it ASAP and not waiting for your other planned features to be finished for one 'big update', because the game suffers a lot of pacing problems as a direct result of ingredient scarcity.

My suggestions:

1. Increase both the number and yield of plants as the game progresses. You could do this via a natural progression (as the player finishes Alchemy Chapters) or as an additional perk for the experience tree.

2. Allow players to plant specific herbs that they need based on a list that they've already "unlocked" from the corresponding merchant potion quest.

I'll elaborate on why I believe the game's pacing needs tweaked. 

I lose way too much money to merchants because I need to buy so many ingredients to keep up with demand, map exploration, alchemy lab recipes, etc. I hardly ever have enough money to buy lab upgrades and expensive ingredients whenever the merchants show up. I believe the low garden yield is the source of these frustrations.

I believe negative reviews for this game are ultimately because it is extremely slow-paced to navigate the map and ingredients run out very fast. I feel like the game risks overstaying its welcome as a result. 

Additionally, I don't think there's any need to make recipe pages another thing you have to buy and unlock. Make the recipe book infinite by default. This will allow players to easily create multiple 'copies' of optimal recipes using different ingredient combinations and further speed up the game's punishing pace. 

I am running out of motivation to fully complete the game because it simply takes too long to do anything. I LOVE the concept and whenever I'm in the mood to strategize the optimal way to navigate the map towards my potion goals, I do enjoy the challenge and steady hand it requires. I feel like I should be progressing much faster than I am, though. It can get exhausting after a while to make potions, especially when I'm constantly running out of the optimal ingredients that I've made a recipe for. The "fun factor" runs out very fast as a result. It can be so much more fun if I felt like I was able to get somewhere beyond a snail's pace.

Also, some people don't like the haggle minigame. I don't mind it but I am good at these kinds of reflex games. I would, however, recommend an 'easy mode' for people who have difficulty with these kinds of minigames but still need to make a bigger profit. (Seriously, it's far too slow to make money in this game as it is!)

TLDR:

1. Make the garden progressively ABUNDANT
2. infinite recipe book pages. At least, give us FAR more than the default amount of pages at first.



It's possible that you guys WANT this game to take forever to 100% complete and you like the pacing as it is. That's fine. It's your game and your vision for it. I do, however, believe that my suggestions would be the popular opinion of the average gamer who doesn't have a lot of time to spend playing games and wants to feel excited and satisfied with this one. 

Thanks for reading.

Potion Craft is a really chill alchemy simulator. While you are still running a shop at the end of the day, profits are easy to come by as you have no operating costs beyond the ingredients, which you get free batches of every day. So you build up a list of recipes and dole out potions to everyone knocking on your door. Then someone asks for something new it's time to get to experimenting. 

The potion making is pretty unique - alchemy effects are spread out on a map, and every ingredient follows a certain path. You have a variety of tools and methods to make slight alterations as you add one ingredient after another, charting a course into the unknown and finally settling on a potion effect you can add to your mixture. Taking a direct route and landing right on the effect gives you the highest selling potion for the fewest ingredients, netting you big profits, so it pays to keep manually making the potion until you've mastered it. Then it goes in the recipe book where, provided the ingredients are available, you can recreate  the potion with a single click. With some savvy trading for more ingredients with merchants you can have a stockpile of everything you need to cover all your clients' needs. 

But all that money has to go somewhere, right? And that's where the game introduces a sort of back-room tinkering aspect. When the shop shuts for the day and there's no more clients, you might decide to brew something truly outrageous just to explore the map and complete challenges, like getting 5 effects in a single potion or finding stuff people haven't even asked for yet. These expensive experiments soak up a ton of ingredients and often then results aren't really useful in the shop. But they work into a narrative relate to every alchemist's dream - making the philosopher's stone. 

Unfortunately, this is where the game can become a little bit of a grind. At times your quest will be locked behind tasks that require specific merchants to come along. Maybe they turn up but you don't have the money to buy what you need, maybe you've got the money saved but you're waiting for days, just filling the same orders for the potions you had recipes for long ago. When you spend more time in the haggling minigame than brewing new and interesting potions, it can start to feel like the game has slowed to a crawl. 

I do like what's here, I love the challenges and I think it's worth playing, but I'd almost want the economy to be even easier because the fun here isn't actually the mundane business of running a shop. It's the late night experiments to create something weird and wonderful.

This is not a game about alchemy. Not exactly. This is a puzzle game with an alchemy theme.

When I bought the game, I was excited. fictional alchemy had always piqued by interest. Potion-making in video games where alchemy is not the focus often becomes underdeveloped, uninteresting, superfluous, or overwritten after some progression. However, my excitement devolved into frustration very quickly.

The game is not terrible, but its focus is wanting. Ingredients in the crafting system are used as pathing tools for carving out a trail towards your desired destination; the destination being the potion effect you want. With this in mind, it does not matter which components you use for your pathing as long as you get to the right destination; I often found myself making potions of healing with an ingredient described as poisonous. I thought that the descriptions of these items would give me clues on what to use for finding a certain potion type (i.e. the customer asks for Strength, maybe the ingredient will mention making people strong) but this exclusively applies to the few ingredients you have in the tutorial because of the narrow scope at said time.

The process of making potions is interesting at the start when you're mapping out the trails like a novice cartographer, and immediately this fascination turns into tedium. I cannot emphasize enough how this does not give me the feeling of making potions, but putting a jigsaw puzzle together, if the puzzle were constantly rotating with three-dimensional shapes instead of flat squares; it is genuinely fun to find a way to arrive at the desired potion effect, but it is such a long process that making the same effect is no longer exciting after the first few times. Luckily, the developers did think of this, and gave you the ability to save your favorite recipes to be immediately crafted on a hotkey. The fatal flaw in this design is that this recipe book has limited pages which you need to upgrade over time, meaning you will not escape the tedium of finding the same effect over and over until you grind enough to have enough pages to make it bearable. 

And after all that work, the prices you get can be rather terrible, and you are better off haggling the price for a potion that is one tier lower than the one you just spent 10 minutes putting together before realizing that Poison+Fire is not the combination they hinted at when wanting to destroy a monster.

At the very least, it got the frustrating feeling of micromanaging your own business right, with having to evaluate what ingredients you need and just how "worth it" it would be to leap across the counter and strangle that ungrateful customer.

Despite all I've said, I will continue to derive fun from this game. I originally did not intend to post a review until I had some hours, but the borderline deceptive core game design made me feel like I had already seen enough. It is not an irredeemable title, but I cannot forgive it for the violin solo it made my heart perform upon witnessing the harrowing display of "not alchemy."

Overall, 5/10. Will continue my search for my perfect alchemy title elsewhere.

Very unique take on a potion-crafting system, and an enjoyable gameplay loop. It's an especially nice game if you're achievement/goal oriented, and if you're a fan of figuring out efficient setups.

Potion crafting is basically a puzzle of moving across a big map to specific points, the challenge being that each individually ingredient moves you across the map differently. To make specific potions, you need to reach specific points that determine an effect. That coupled with the "experience point" bubbles to grab as you go, and the general challenge of both acquiring ingredients and making good use of the ones you manage to get ahold of keep things interesting as you try to build up your ingredient supply to go for the costly, over-arching crafts that make up the bigger-picture progression. All the while, you're running a shop to sell potions to folks, requiring that you make quality potions to sell at prices that let you buy out the said ingredients you need.

A way to summarize the gameplay loop is you start a day, grab some free ingredients from your garden, sell to some folks and buy out what you can from merchants. Once you feel you've got a good supply (Or are waiting for certain progression upgrades to show up in said merchants), you start experimenting with exploring the potion map to find more potion effects and marking down shortcuts, or getting to work on making those complex potions you need for advanced recipes.

Really unique system to see and experience, even if you don't feel like sticking to the end of the game. Highly recommend checking it out.

The game says it's fully released. It is not. This review will be updated once that's actually the case.

The content that's currently in the early and mid stage of the game is fun and polished, and other reviews will talk about them more. However, the playable content is enjoyable up to a point where you realize the game expects to you make use of features that's clearly not actually implemented yet: a third potion base and upgraded equipment/garden. 

Customers would demand, say, a tier 3 potion of inspiration. The problem is, without the wine base, you'll have to dump ingredients or use a hard to obtain mineral to reach the that part of the alchemy map, then dump a load of moon/sun salt to rotate it just right for it to be tier 3. What do you get for all that trouble? 500 coins. Declining the customer would net you a pretty hefty penalty at higher reputations too. 

On top of that, creating potions/recipes from scratch requires you to grind a lot of ingredients down, and even with the accessibility feature turned on, you'd give yourself repetitive motion injury by playing this game in a session longer than an hour.

I would not recommend this game until at least these two problems are fixed.

Some small tips to help anyone that may be confused about UI bits and any future issues one may come across. Anything I think might be too 'spoilery' for those that like to figure their heads, I'll be sure to black out.

1. The compass points you towards the focal point of the potions in their direction (example, life points to health potion. death points to poison)
2. The whirlpools [spoiler]can be rotated by pumping air into the fire. Careful doing this if atop a potion effect you do not want.[/spoiler]
3. Whirlpools cont. [spoiler]Getting sucked into a whirlpool will warp your potion elsewhere. Upon warping via whirlpool, it will be permanently marked on your map where the destination was for future use[/spoiler]
4. Recipe book pages CAN be discounted, but you may still want to buy a handful in advance to be safe.
5. Be sure to thoroughly explore [spoiler]                  oil.                                     [/spoiler] That way you don't get stuck like I did for several in-game weeks.
6. Any truly disastrous, unsellable potions can be sold to merchants for 0 gold. Otherwise they can't be removed.
7. Adding to a recipe BEFORE you apply the potion effect can let you save an optimized path for further exploration (useful when finding unknown effects)
8. First bartering tier unlock is quite good.
9. Don't waste stones. [spoiler]They're used to teleport the distance that they're ground to. But the merchants that sell them don't bring a lot, and don't stop by as often as the others. Imo always stock up even if they're marked up[/spoiler]

A missed opprotunity.

It's a good game, but I can't really recommend it because it is certainly unfinished. Aside from the lack of sounds (when pick up flowers at least), the repetitive gameplay and the randomness, it's missing a very important thing - the story. It is almost non-existent in the game as is, but you could at least tell more stories with the customers coming and going. There are 3 types of customers in the game right now:
1) Merchants: you buy stuff and sometimes give potions for them to bring new ingredients;
2) Random buyers: they tell what kind of a potion they need. Usually there are more than one type of a potion that fits their requests;
3) Story characters: there are only 2 of them in the game - the Fisherman and the Witcher. However, they just disappear (or rather never come back) after a certain number of requests of like 5-8 or something along the lines.

While I understand that the main focus of the game was on the "brewing" part of the game - and it is fun for what it is - you could make SO much more even with random customers. A quick example would be something like this: you sell a poison potion to a customer for them to poison their neighbour's well, while the next day another customer comes and asks for an explosion potion to destroy their neighbour's house, because they were poisoned. --And one could make at least a dozen of these overnight.

The game has other flaws as I mentioned, but this one is truly a missed opportunity. If you want a casual game for a couple of hours then yes - I could you recommend this game for its price. Otherwise, you'll be left disappointed.

A very pretty and very gripping, but ultimately boring grind. A super nice experience on the surface, but as of 1.0 release, it seriously lacks content.

- No plot or story of any kind. NPCs are absurdly dull. Despite the "reputation" system being in place, there's no story-driven decision-making in giving specific kinds of potions to specific people (which was so well done this year in "Strange Horticulture").

- No variety. Only two maps are not enough. The sequence of all tasks is exactly the same after ~10h. The "soundtrack" is one single repetitive piece looped over and over (!!!). There's no equipment upgrades or variations. Why can't I switch my "wooden spoon" with some "golden spoon" that would work differently?

- No challenge. After ~15h you're rolling in money and ingredients and can do literally whatever you want. The customers with very particular demands are still fun, because they give you fun puzzles to solve (and all of them seem solvable so far, which is a huge plus). But to *get the fun customers to come* you need to grind through hundreds of boring ones. I'd love some "hard mode" that only gives you the most demanding customers and is actually punishing in some interesting way if you don't manage to serve them (e.g. limits your potion-making abilities). Also there's no achievements for those fun challenges, even though they would be perfect for that.

I'm happy to wait a year or two to see if this gets any meaningful updates, but for now I can't really recommend it over many better games.

To review this game, I'm gonna use a food analogy.

This game is like an fried egg. Why? Well, that happens to be my current favorite way to cook and eat an egg. No other real reason.

If you don't like eggs, you're not going to want a fried egg no matter how it's cooked, and if you like eggs, but only like deviled eggs, you aren't going to want a fried egg.

But, if you like a good fried egg than look no further! This is the meal for you.

Potion Craft is sort of like a point-and-click game with elements of planning and exploration. The game can roughly be split into 3 parts: 

- Resource Management
- Planning/Exploration
- NPC interaction

Let's start with the last one. A large portion of the game is interacting with customers, trying to figure out what potion they want and making it for them. The interactions aren't very deep, but they can be fun at times.

The Planning and exploration part of the game is really the "meat and potatoes" of the gameplay loop. You have an "alchemy" map which starts out unexplored. In the center is a potion of water. By adding different ingredients to your cauldron, you can start to plan out a path for your potion of water to take. Stirring the cauldron starts your potion moving down your planned path, with your eventual goal to be to reveal new potions and prepositionally line up your potion of water with the new potion you've discovered.

The potion making gameplay is a bit more complex than that, but it somewhat fits into the: "easy to learn, hard to master" category.

One of the main complexities with the Exploration/Planning portion of the game is Resource Management: over the course of the game, you will find yourself short on certain ingredients and will need to make due with what you have. You also have a strong incentive to make your potions as cheaply as possible. I really enjoy this: there's something satisfying about making an excellent potion with very few ingredients.

For me, the biggest CON of the of the game is that as you explore more of the map, it can be harder and harder to get to previously discovered potions. There's a recipe system where you can save a potion, and without it, the game would be way too monotonous. However, if you've just spent 20 minutes and several expensive ingredients to explore and find a new potion, you probably aren't going to want to save it to a recipe, instead, you'll need to spend another 20+ minutes planning how to get back over to the potion, but this time being resource conscious.

Another hard part of the game (which becomes much harder later) is that sometimes a customer will want a potion you have yet to discover. The game is very smart and doesn't put any sort of time-limit to serving a customer, but it can be daunting to have to explore the map for a new potion when you have little to no idea where it will be (the earlier potions sort of have a system, but as far as I know, that system kinda becomes useless later in the game)

Anyway, to end this rather long and ramble-y review: I really enjoy this game. There are enough new things to keep me interested and the gameplay isn't too demanding.

If you want a chill single-player experience, give this game a try!

I adore this game. I think it is a great spin on the "alchemist" trope, where the player has much more freedom than just following a set recipe. Each ingredient follows a set path and you can chain together different ingredients to reach the same potion effect. If you are running low on one ingredient, just use another. It may not be the most optimal path, but it gets the job done. I also enjoy that the game is not just selling potions to the customer, you also have the option to brew potions for yourself in order to research the philosopher's stone. Resource management is a very big thing in Potion Craft, as you want the recipes you save to be as low-cost as possible and with the most readily-available ingredients so you can use that recipe more often. I also enjoy the characters that come through to buy your potions. They are great at showing the world outside of the potion shop. Some of them might come through, saying that they are a knight and need to be stronger and faster. In that case, you can put two potions into one and create a potion of strength and swiftness. That isn't to say that this game is perfect though.

There is 2 things that bug me: the exploration of the outer parts of the potion map and portals. The outer part of the map is more maze like, increasing the chance for your potions to fail. This alone isn't a deal breaker though. I think that the further you get from the center, the more difficult the potions should be to brew. It's the fact that a lot of these potions require many, many ingredients to get to. So much so that often times I find that brewing a potion from the outer portion of the map does not cover the cost of the ingredients that go into it. A lot of those potions just aren't worth the investment.

The portals also do not make much sense. I'd say a good portion of the portals are either gimmick (just one time use to get some experience) or actively work against you. Some portals send you backwards, away from the potions you are trying to brew, especially the portals on the outer edges of the map. I find myself using the portals less than I'd like to. I wish they were more useful, a good way to save an extra ingredient in the brewing process. Some are designed like that, but I wish that most were designed like that.

Overall, I think the game is great. It's not a game you can spend an entire day playing, but a great game if you want to unwind after a day at work for an hour or two. I don't see myself putting 100 hours into Potion Craft anytime soon, but I do think I'll be playing it off and on for the foreseeable future.

3 nights in a row, I wanted to play it. I booted it up with the want to play and genuinely enjoyed it for about 45-60 minutes each time. But after that, I'd finish a day (in game) and question why bother doing another day. Progression doesn't feel great. There are milestones like checklists for the chapter of your lesson book and you get skill points to just do more of the same thing -- not even do it much better, just.. more. Nearly every upgrade you get doesn't make the game easier. It makes you have to do the hard stuff more often. You get more customers that want the potions that require specific materials which is great the first time. You do the whole alchemical exploration process to find it and that puzzle solving is fun. It's unique and I genuinely felt like I was brewing and discovering a potion. You can save the recipe to expedite it the next time a customer wants it which was wonderful for easy potions. But the recipe saves the exact process you did - exact ingredients and all. So if you don't have enough of a single ingredient that went a certain direction, you have to do that whole process again and it's way less fun to make a difficult potion the second or third or forth time. If you have the exact stuff, then awesome and you make a ton of money. But money is just more "progression."

The game is fun to start but the reward for progression is increased difficulty with little to none of the quality of life or ease you tend to get with progression. And to be fair, there may be things further down the line. I made the first big alchemical machine thing, felt a smidge of serotonin, checked to see what the next one would need and immediately went "fuck that".

Art style is great and I'll probably pick it up for an hour once a month. Tough to recommend otherwise.

I am in love with this game, its concept, and its execution. 
It gets the best part of alchemy systems with an interesting game play function. The alchemy map and its progression system is very reminiscent of rouge-lites and their own style of progression, with the interesting premise that you're just an alchemist, exploring the arcane nature of the ingredients with a fun science to it.

My favorite part of the game has to be the fact that you are given many attempts to recreate the potion, and in the most efficient way possible. The only complaint I have is how little and how expensive ingredients are. But I do believe that the upcoming updates will add new ways to get ingredients., so holding my tongue on the topic until anything comes out is a good idea.  

The merchant system is interesting in the way its built, especially around the fact that you have a rotation of customers with these merchants sprinkled in between. Again, my complain from before about the expensive ingredients remain prevalent with the merchants. As well as the fact that I don't see a real reason in keeping price differences if there can't be a regular supply of them. Maybe restructuring the merchant system as a sort of supply line system for your store? That way, prices do matter, in addition to the fact you can set up a consistent supply of one resource that maybe isn't too available in your garden. Or cheap ingredients that are used regularly for movement in the map (the main directional ingredients) 
It would make an interesting market system in the world that we as the players can interact with. 

I digress, I do wish there could be more done with trading than just random merchants.

The core gameplay loop of Potion Craft is map exploration: you use a variety of ingredients to move your potion around a map filled with dead zones that reset your progress. You grind them to modify the path they take, use minerals to warp through hazards, add water to make incremental modifications to your position, and gradually explore more of the map. As you go you unlock more and more potion effects.

This core experience is great: you get asked for a potion that can help unblock a tunnel, or improve someone's combat ability, and then make them something with one or more effects. You buy stuff, help solve problems for your suppliers, and gradually improve your potion shop. You can save a limited but upgradeable number of recipes to save time. So far so good.

The problem is with the mid to late-game content. I explored the whole map pretty quickly, unlocked huge amounts of ingredients, and after that the core gameplay loop became very stale. The mid-game and late-game objectives are all around brewing a LOT of potions with arbitrary combinations of effects, for use in alchemy or for clients with exacting demands. The problem is, there's no exploration by this point: you're just opening up the same map(s) you've seen a million times, going to the same effects you've already used, and trying not to slip up. Half your recipes won't work because you accidentally used a rare ingredient that the merchants no longer stock, and even then, starting from one or two effects out of five doesn't save much time. It becomes routine detail-oriented busywork instead of challenging new exploration.

Overall I really enjoyed the first 7 or 8 hours, but would have preferred it if the game stayed about exploration, and became more challenging and less grindy towards the end. It promises so much, but doesn't quite get there.
I recommend this game.

Potion Craft: Alchemist Simulator is a very enjoyable simulator in which you brew and discover various recipes to fit your client's needs.
They come to you with their interesting little stories like poisoning someone they dislike, or because they suffer from diarrhea and need a health potion to get rid of it.

You get to harvest plants and mushrooms alike while you can also buy them from vendors coming to your shop during business hours.
As you sell and create potions you also have to upgrade some parts of your brewing station that is there to craft high-tier quality stuff that you need to complete the main quests of the game.

The map on which you discover new potions is the only thing that, in my eyes, is a bit of a negative point.
It can be frustrating to craft potions if you crash into a bone wall because you happened to be a bit too close to it, and you have to restart the brewing from zero again.

 By selling potions you get clients that want their potions for crimes and others to improve their own or the life of others, which results in either a bad or a good shop reputation.
This influences which customers are more likely to appear in your shop.
The worse the reputation, the more customers that desire your potions for bad stuff will visit your shop.
I really did like that mechanic of the game.

The last part that I found frustrating is the higher recipes that require a lot of potions and higher tier stuff that may be a pain to obtain as you can't save the recipes for these.

(And I still don't know what potion this mushroom guy wants, hence why he refuses to sell me more mushrooms.)
