8 hours in. This game has some fantastically implemented mechanical ideas - for example, I love the map exploration aspect of recipe building, and I'm a sucker for any game that involves creative use of limited resources. I truly feel the developers have hit something special with the core of the game. That said, advancing through chapters can quickly devolve into an unsatisfying grind after about chapter 5, and certain features such as haggling only become more annoying as the game drags on. I feel with some pacing adjustments, addition of variety in the characters and writing, and some variation on top of the core features (which again, I do love), this game could really be fun. 

One simple fix to the pacing would be to have the traveling merchants able to be visited at any time by the player. The developers could still maintain ingredient randomness and scarcity by varying what each merchant has on a given day (as well as costs). With the current mechanic, it can be very frustrating when you are waiting for one particular mechant (who sells parts to the alchemist machine) to return to advance the chapters, or when you wish you could just revisit a merchant when you just need one little bump to finish a recipe. 

Overall, I do recommend this game, and I'll be keeping an eye on it for updates, but I don't blame people who grow tired of the game's loop only a few hours in.

I noticed that a lot of the positive reviews are from early access, so I'm leaving my own. I've enjoyed what I've done so far. Potion making is fun to do for the first time, and then every subsequent time you can automake the potion the same way if you save it. I also like acquiring vast sums of wealth, and although I haven't tried level 4/5 bartering, level 3 is easy enough for me to have only failed one so far, and I barter almost every time. The game looks great as well, at least as far as it tries to (for example: people aren't animated, but the day transition is gorgeous, and the artstyle works). I'm a little mixed about exploration, though it's been lots of fun so far I've reached the point where the unexplored areas are long unsubstantiated corridors so I need to either use a rock to skip through them (which I don't think was explained? though I also mainly skim instructions) or spend a nerve wracking amount of ingredients exploring. The desire to make an efficient recipe goes against the books scattered about, because you can either make sure the recipe you save is worth using or not save the recipe and go back later, though that's probably an early game thing and you'll always have to go back and plan out a better route later on. Anyways, the real thing I wanted to complain about was the abysmal progression system. Somewhat hyperbolic, but I had everything completed for tier 3 except for the "purchase an alchemy table" portion by day 5 and the person who sells the alchemy table did it on some double digit numbered day. Now I'm on tier 4 on day 20, having done everything except for "create the magic substance" and I have every potion needed, but there's a mineral required that I haven't seen since day 5, where it was marked up and I was only passingly aware that I needed it. The dwarf just showed up, and he had three rocks that weren't the ones required for progression. I almost have chapter 5 finished, and yet chapter 4 alludes me.
So yeah, progression is random and all I can do is get stupidly wealthy off of these bandits who keep coming to me (because I got a streak of bad people and now I'm evil aligned, oh well). Don't get me wrong, I like the game, and I'm almost certain I'm going to put more time in, but these are my gripes. Exploration can feel wasteful in the short run, progression isn't entirely in your hands, though leveling up does spike the request difficulty which I did notice when I hit level 3 in 2 days. Early game ingredients can be scarce, but if you barter every time money is not so buy out anything discounted and probably everything not. TLDR good game, would buy again.

So I was really expecting to like this one and bought it as soon at 1.0 hit, thinking it was really my sort of game. Unfortunately, it really fell flat for me.

The potion-making core gameplay (95% of the game with a bit of ancilliary stuff which is basically working out which potions you need) is a simplistic maze game where you move through a repetitive and slow process. Unlike many of these high-concept, high-theme indie games, this process never changes or develops, rather you just have to go further into the maze later in the game. Once you have played for ten minutes you have seen everything this game has to offer.

This would be fine if the core gameplay was really fun but it isn't. It's kind of intriguing at first and I like the abstraction of representing chemistry with a maze but ultimately it's just a very basic maze game where you have to go through three steps (always the same three steps) to move anywhere.

I put up with this for a while (14 hours in fact), hoping that the game would develop some new twist on the formula or significantly speed up the exponentially-increasing grind to reach the next level. It did not, and it's a shame.

Pros:
Theming is great - looks and sounds fantastic
Concept of alchemy expressed as a maze input game is interesting

Dependent on tastes:
I really think this would be better if you could buy ingredients at any time - when you end up with loads of money but no ingredients that let you move in a certain direction it's very frustrating.

Cons:
Repetitive beyond all belief
Grindy, with the later recipes requiring a total repeat of ALL earlier ones
Some of the requests can be annoyingly vague: 'I want a potion to stop my fruit from going rotten.' Is that a rejuvenation potion? A growth potion? A necromancy potion? An ice potion? I honestly never figured it out.
The save recipe shortcut doesn't really work as is for any but the most basic potions (the ones you need the shortcut for the least) because you will use so many ingredients you inevitably won't have the same ones next time - again, something that being able to buy ingredients on the fly would help with.
The perfect thing to hyper-fixate on, and they are ambitiously updating the game. A very interactive but relaxing game. I'd recommend it to about anyone.

I want to praise Potion Craft, but looking back, the first things that come to my mind are not gentle.

It's an exercise in tedium.
It's a minigame that is missing its main game.
It's repetitive, slow, devoid of content and full of nothing. 
It's a fluff sandwich. 
It's a chore and feels like a real job after a while. 

I know it sounds harsh, but let me explain.
The first few hours of the game are *amazing*. The game gives you a very simple explanation and lets you have a go at it, pace yourself, play however you want, and for as long as you are working unraveling the initial water chart, figuring the simplests of potions, you really are there. 
It's in the progression where the game falls flat. 
You'd think to expect a story, more mechanics perhaps, some sudden change in stakes that ups the ante and makes the management part of the game more nuanced, perhaps? Perhaps more uses for gold? 
No. That's it. 
You buy reagents, sometimes you are allowed to buy an upgrade for the alchemical machine, which in itself is nothing but a checklist of very specific formulas you have to find in order to progress, and eventually win the game. At some point you will be given access to other base reagents - you start with water - that come with different charts. The charts offer some slight variability, but the recipes in them are the same. 

This game is simply incomplete. It needed more meat, not 900 more random NPCs with a vague backstory and some indication for what potion they need. 
If there's such meat in this game, after 9 hours playing I haven't found it, and that's as far as I am willing to give it until a considerable update.

I...am ashamed of how much time I've packed on to this game from the short time I have had it. It's addictive for personalities such as mine, 

I love grinding up the ingredients so much -- especially the gems! I love that you have to actually tap to break them before you can grind them...and the animation of how it 'forms' is beautiful and mesmerizing. I am addicted and my family has missed me for the past 12 hours. 

The crafting system is really fun, and you can master it over time and patience. I love it. I see high potential in this game as it 'evens' out the bugs and issues and possibly add new features in the future? (no idea if they will)

That being said - here are the hard facts for this game at its current state (1.0):

* It crashes constantly for a lot of people - even those with the minimum requirements to run it. Dev team is working on it, and you can report the issues on their Discord.
I-------->You can save yourself the deep depression of losing your progress by saving as often as you want. (I personally save after every "big" thing I accomplish - like a level 3 potion, or a new potion, or a new part).

* Can feel very limited at times, as you get stuck in places, or screw up your inventory and mess around too much trying to brew crazy stuff.

* There ARE glitches. Lots of glitches -- but again, you can report them to the Dev team on Discord, and they seem to take the feedback well.

Overall, this game gets an 8/10 from me. I'm easy to pleasey, though. 

I take off two stars for the constant crashing, and that the fact the answer right now typically is, "your computer can't handle it/is outdated". I can play No Man's Sky flawlessly...this game should NOT be an issue, but I honestly just blame Unity - because it's Unity. You can fart and Unity will freak out and stop working.

I highly recommend that patient people like myself ignore the crashing for now if you can run your game for an hour or two without it exploding, and save often.

For those of you who hate anticipating when a crash will happen, or you forget to save often, or you're just not into dealing with crashes - don't buy this game until it improves its stability. Join their Discord and watch for updates.

I like the visuals and the whole medieval aesthetic. 

If all you plan on doing is burn through your stash of reagents to explore the formula map then this game is a pretty nice way to spend a couple of hours. But if you're looking to progress through the game, then you'll probably find yourself facing a bit of frustration. 

There's way too much RNG involved in this for a game that's tagged relaxing. 

You only obtain reagents two ways: 
1) Randomly generated each game day in your garden
2) Purchase from the occasional merchant whose stock is also randomly generated. 

The customers that come in are similarly randomly generated in their requests so you never know what reagents you should set aside. Sometimes they even ask for potions you've yet to discover and there are no hints on the direction you should explore, so you wind up wasting a lot of reagents just discovering random potions. As a result, your exploration of the formula map is quite severely curbed. 

There also aren't enough perks to levelling up. You get talent points for doing so, which allows you to improve the radius of your exploration, or make sales/purchases more lucrative, but none of these actually address the ultimate problem of no way to reliably increase your reagents or make your brews more efficient. 

Would be good if we had some level upgrades so that a single brew may produce more than one potion, or the garden could be 'tuned' in some way so that more herbs of a certain element/direction will grow the following day to better manage stock. 

That said, we're still in v1.0, so I'm curious and hopeful for more improvements in the future.

I'd love to recommend this game. I got it while it was still in Early Access around fall 2021, and enjoyed the content at the time a lot. I was excited for the full release.

Unfortunately, terrible optimization makes the current version unplayable. Literally - it crashes on launch, and the devs respond to these issues by citing insufficient GPU.

To be fair, my PC is pretty old. But it also runs games like Dishonored, XCOM, Oxygen Not Included, Disco Elysium and The Sims 3+4 with no real issues. I really don't see why it should fail to run a simple 2D crafting game unless some truly terrible decisions were made under the hood. Many, many people on the forums are having this same issue, many of them with much more advanced hardware than what I have.

I'll revise this review if the devs improve optimization post-launch, but until then... Yeah.

Interesting concept, mostly fun so far. I have run into a few glaring bugs (such as potions showing tier 3 effect and saying cannot make without an effect) but seeing as its quite a recent release, hopefully these bugs get fixed quickly. 

The game center around making potions, you can harvest or buy various ingredients which will affect the potion, moving it some way around a "potion map" on this map there are various affects, navigate your potion to an effect to make a potion with that effect, such as healing, frost, etc. The more on point you potion is the higher the effect level. Potions can also have multiple effects. Say, healing and wild growth or poison and healing. It's not all tedious as you are given the option to "save recipes" if you make a tier 3 fire potion you can save it so you can remake it whenever without navigation as long as you have the same ingredients you made it with.

The game encourages creativity and experimentation in a fun way. Unfortunately  at this time I have been encountering bugs with saving potions and creating potions which have made this game not quite fun. I'll try to give it a go in a few weeks and see if these launch bugs are fixed, until then I cannot wholeheartedly recommend this game.

EDIT: Finding out the game did have an early access period dampens my hope considerably. If the game had an early access period then saying it launched yesterday is not quite true making me less hopeful that the bugs I encountered will be fixed soon.

At nine and a half hours in (day 46 I think?) I've hit a point where I'm just sort of grinding to get enough resources to conveniently search around for [spoiler]resist poison (I'm guessing?)[/spoiler] so that I can give it to the merchants.  I also unlocked a new base, [spoiler]oil instead of water[/spoiler] [strike]but in my initial testing it seems [/strike][spoiler][strike]to be on the exact same potion map[/strike] it is not the same[/spoiler] [strike]which is not very interesting.[/strike]

That being said, these are my only serious complaints.  My first problem would be easily solved by a limited-use freebie-discovery type thing so if you get stuck trying to find a specific potion (or just hate searching) you can make it happen much easier.  My second problem might not even be a problem, we'll see when I continue to progress.  I also think there should have been a tutorial explaining that the gems teleport your potion on the map allowing you to traverse walls.

Other than that, the game is great!  Very fun, great design, addicting game loop (I played the first 9.5 hours all at once).  Well worth the price for me already, especially on sale, but still a decent pick up at full price.  The dialogue is cute with a few great references, I'm only a bit confused at the morality assigned to some of the stories customers tell you.  It's medieval fantasy so you can assume everyone exists under an oppressive feudal system, but when you help clearly disheveled poor people steal food from castles or run from guards it is considered immoral.  Then helping those wealthy nobles in certain contexts is considered moral.  Robin Hood anyone?  I guess not.

Overall, an 8 or 9 out of 10 for me so far, will update if I finish the game or get farther and change my mind.
